I was upgraded to this seat and feared it would be regrettable due to the proximity to the galley.  However, the forward galley really wasn't used so it was very quiet and low foot traffic up front.  I was on a domestic flight (PHL-SFO) so this may different when the plane is on a TATL route.
I flew on this plane with the new premium economy seats in July 2018 and seats 8A and 8H do not have windows.

Sat in Premium Economy.  Seat was wider and had great leg room.  Only problem was the headphone port.  It was situated in the very back of the armrest, preventing me from being able to plug it in.  The flight attendant even mentioned the need to "be a contortionist."  I wanted to see a movie but unfortunately could not due to this issue.  But luckily I had a book with me so I just read.  I had submitted a comment regarding this to aa.com so I wonder if they fixed this problem.  So if you are in Premium Economy, bring a book or your own tablet for entertainment in case you cannot access the jack.

My flight from PHL to MAN on a 767-300 was pure torture, so this flight back to PHL from LON was luxurious by comparison. The seats are reasonably comfortable for a person 5'9", and the recline was good. The crew was efficient if not especially friendly, and the service (meal, ice cream, water, snack) was good for economy.  One lavatory malfunctioned and was blocked off, but others sufficed. In all, a decent trans-Atlantic experience.
This seat does not have an air vent. A minor issue for most people.

Although this seat row has a bulkhead / toilet behind the seats recline as much as all others in the same cabin. I flew HNL-PHX and it was most comfortable for an Economy seat in 2019. Slept most of the flight, without interuption,

This was the best seat, best flight ever (except for the fabulous return), US to Italy and back. I wish this plane was used for long flights within the US, like to/from Hawaii (if you know it is, tell me!), although Hawaiian's 330-200 is very close.

This seat is marked as not having a window. This was not the case for me, flying this seat on this bird from FCO-CLT a week ago. It not only had a window, but a nice clean one with a great view. Perhaps someone is confusing this with the A330-200? 

Separately, I have to say that this seat was great. It's a standard economy seat, but offered at least 32 inches of seat pitch, which felt like a ton of room compared to my inbound flight to Italy on Alitalia, where I only had 31 inches of pitch. I'm 6'7'', so I have become pretty adept at sensing pitch without a tape measure. The seat itself was very comfy and well padded with a great adjustable headrest. IFE was very good, only thing is you have to really press the screen hard to get it to respond. FA's were super friendly and routinely circulated with water and drinks. Food was also exceptionally good and abundant in quantity, particularly for coach. We also had individual air vents overhead, which is great. 

So sad that AA is soon to remove the A330-300 from its fleet! This was one of the best flights across the pond in coach that I have ever had! It blew my experience flying Alitalia out of the water, and I'm usually biased against AA!

Of the seats you don't have to pay to upgrade to, this is one of the best on the plane, in my opinion. At this point in the plane, there are only three seats in the middle row, which means there is more room between you and the fellow across the aisle. There are also three seats in front of you, so the entertainment monitor is directly in front of you, which is not the case in row 37. Overall, at least on the 330s, American Airlines' entertainment monitors are as crap as crap can be. You have to put all of your weight into pressing the touchscreen, which is very inconveniencing to the person in front of you. I've flown on American A330s four times now, and that has been consistently the case.

Obviously a more recent A330 aircraft.  Seats on the left have less legroom, while seats on the right have more legroom.  Both scenarios require additional fees. But since one mostly sleeps on the way to Europe, we did not mind being a bit more cramped.  On the way back we booked seats on the right because the flight lasts a lot longer.

Seat for DUB-PHL was in MCE and comfortable, but the space between the seat and the bulkhead was a little wide to lean on for sleeping.  The touchscreens are laggy, which was super-annoying as the person behind us was playing a video game and constantly jostling the seat.  We finally had to speak to him and he kept doing it.  AA needs to remove the games, period.  Most people who want games bring their own these days.

Cabin crew was attentive and kind.  Meals were typical skimpy coach meals (bleh) - basically a Lean Cuisine with a lot of starchy sides.  But they did a nice job coming through multiple times with beverages, which made it easier to stay hydrated.

I am generally satisfied with AA business class seating on 777 and 787s. I fly them regularly (at least once a month). However this A330 aircraft which I believe is an older USAIR tail has the most awful business class seating. Extremely uncomfortable in almost all orientations.   My suggestion is to avoid any American A330 based aircraft.

As the corridor narrows around the toilet, sitting in 25F means that you will get your toes trodden on several times during the night flight home. 5 times if I am anything to judge by! 
This will also be true of the opposite side 25C

There is no storage space, except for the over-head compartment.  And has a small tray and desk top area.  The foot rest does not have its' own separate control and only comes up when you are moving the seat to the recline position.  The space was not very private ( especially versus Business Class seat on American Airlines' 77W ), but maybe a bit larger than on the 77W.

Flew overnight HNL to PHX.  Seat was comfortable both sitting and fully flat.  I personally thought the pillow was oversized for the space you have at the head of the bed.  Good choice of movies but as previously reported, the in flight entertainment screen can be slow to respond.  The system on our flight had to be reset about 45 minute into the flight.  One downside to row 6-the lavatories are nearby, but the doors don't close automatically.  The light is relatively bright so when someone leaves the lav and does not close the door, it can be annoying.  It would be even worse for row 7.  I got up twice to close the door.  Would be nice if the FA's would notice or AA would fix the problem.

These seats were quite comfortable.  The entertainment system was slow, but it worked.  No Wifi on this plane.  It was supposedly installed but not hooked up (so said the cabin crew).  It was still a comfortable way to spend the 7 hours from Phoenix to Honolulu

Seat was very comfortable with plenty of legroom for 6'2" man.  The video monitors were unfortunately of poor quality with slow or no response to touch.  Movie selection was good and resolution was fine, once you finally got it to respond.     Very nice experience, overall. By comparison, I flew on a BA 747 on outbound leg and seats were miserable.

7H is the last pod in Business Class before the mid-plane galley. It is right up against the toilet bulkhead.  The good news is you don't have far to go to the toilet. The bad news is you may be disturbed by those using the toilet and by crew in the galley.  Otherwise, a comfortable seat.
People are regularily stepping in to avoid other passengers coming down aisle so lot of activity beside you when you sit there

This plane was fairly new, probably only a year or so old.  This was a good seat.  In fact, if it hadn't been for the loud Greeks behind me who talked the ENTIRE 11 hour flight from Athens to Philly, this probably would have been one of the best flights I've ever taken.  I don't know how you can possibly talk for 11 hours straight at the top of your lungs, but the three of them sure did!  We got lots of decent snacks, plus pretty much all the wine you wanted.  I was impressed.
comfortable and more legroom than I thought. Able to stretch out legs under seat in front and I am nearly 6 feet tall and weigh 15 stone.

Flight AA732 CLT-LHR was fantastic - we were seated in row 38, which provided us with plenty of leg room, an entertaining and lively crew and excellent food. The entertainment system worked fine with a good amount of movies available and the close to 8hrs on the brand-new looking A330 went by quickly and smoothly. Thank you so much for a great experience, we will be flying American Airlines more often! Please pass on our compliments to the staff who have made this such an enjoyable experience.

I picked 40H seat to be by the window and assuming that noone, unless faced with no other choice, would choose the seat 40G, so close to the toilet. This was a concern for me too but in the end it was a good choice: I had two seats for myself, no-one poking the back of my seat and enjoyed magnificent views.

It was a night flight and not completely full so I didn't notice a lot of people going to the toilet. I didn't really pay attention and that's great news, as in fact, I couldn't hear nor smell anything (my big worry!). I was happy with the seat choice.

What WAS annoying was the unresponsive touchscreen. I had to tap it so many times and trying so many different spots and angles, I was worried I'd accidentally poke the man in front of me in the head! That made feel good about noone seating behind me.

All the more frustrating as there was a wide selection of entertainment. Movies, recent as well as old. TV shows, games, audio cds. The flight CLT-LHR was over in no time.

AA flight attendants reminded me of teachers who'd been teaching the same stuff for over 20 years and just didn't care much any more, just going through the motions. What a shame as it really dampens the experience.

I have flown on this airplane several times between PHL and Munich over the past few months, all in economy. I have found this plane to be extremely uncomfortable and miserable. There are no main cabin extra seats on the plane, so everything is the same 31" pitch seat that a tall person like me needs a can opener to fit in. The best seats are the bulkhead seats in row 25 and row 8, but you still can't stretch your legs out. My best strategy is to pick an open row and hope it stays open so I can stretch out sideways.

There is USB charging at each seat, but do not expect much from the IFE. The touch screen is completely unresponsive to make it impossible to enjoy any entertainment. Not only that, you will get frustrated with the person behind you repeatedly tapping the screen trying to get it to work.

Finally, I find it odd that they reserve 4 prime seats for crew use.  The exit row seats in row 25 (A,B,G,H) are marked off for crew use, and covered by a curtain during the flight. In a plane where there is a frustratingly low availability of prime seats for elite travelers, I wonder why they would take four of the best ones.

CLT-LHR.  Had limited choice so risked 25F, it was a mistake.  The toilets basically serve all of economy so are busy all the time, that wouldn't be so bad but the light inside is not guarded so act as a floodlight everytime the doors opens.

The rest of the plane was no better, it only had 5V USB, but at such a low ampage it could only charge a phone, an Ipad was actively draining when used.  The avod screen was also useless, with every selection taking 10-20 presses like some 15 year old resistive screen.  All screens had the problem, not just the armrest versions, with the whole plane thumping away on them. 

No idea how old this plane is, but the cigarette stub panels all over it give a clue, its time it met its maker.

Just flew Rome/Phila in August, in economy row 17.  Seats are leather, which is nice.  Leg room is very limited and cramped.  Movie selection is poor., touch monitors were almost impossible to use - not sensitive enough to the touch.  Was surprised about the entertainment being so poor, seems like AA has gone downhill since my last trip to Europe last year.

The legroom on this seat was really nice. However like any bulkhead seat I couldn't stretch my legs all the way out (I'm 5'10") like you can under normal seats.  The seats were new/nice but the AVOD touchscreen barely responded, kind of terrible, that. But good movie selection. I would recommend this seat.

My husband & I just flew in these seats to Rome on 5/11/2016. The ONLY thing they have good about them is extra leg room. AA should pay you to sit in these! Horrible seats! Almost all of economy uses these bathrooms. All of the forward economy passengers have to use these too. Most of the time there was a queue of 6-12 people hovering right in front of us to use the toilets which had become quite smelly after a couple of hours. The majority of the flight attendants could have cared less about any service & were just in a hurry to scurry off to take a nap or convene in back with each other. Will never fly this plane or flight again. We cannot believe we payed extra to fly in these seats.

My partner and I just flew on this aircraft from Rome to Charlotte.  This particular aircraft seemed to be "newer" and was in decent shape.  The IFE touchscreen was sluggish, and the movie selection was so-so.  There were a few current releases of interest.  Since the aircraft was only 50% full, there was plenty of room to spread out, and the flight attendants were very responsive.  Overall, I thought the flight was pleasant.  Seat 30G and 30H provide a nice view of the wing, though it is noisier in the rear section of the plane.
Great crew and very comfortable seat for Business Class. Older plane but everything in good working order. While I prefer the new Boeing 777-300 series , this is a comfortable  flight.

Ex-USAirways plane.  USAirways took delivery of these planes starting in 1996, and some of them look like they are almost twenty years old.  However, the sometimes threadbare appearance, balky IFE, and minor maintenance issues can be overlooked because they are very comfortable.

My flight had no AC power outlets. Not even DC power. No power was a huge disappointment since I wanted to to watch my own movies on my laptop. The crew said the USB ports weren't active, tho I didn't try. 

I wouldn't pick the bulkhead again. The seats are more uncomfortable with the tray table in the armrest.
The main cabin extra seats only have the car lighter power outlet under the seat. Make sure to take with you a car lighter power outlet to charge the phone etc.

Half of the under-seat storage in front is taken by an entertainment box, so there is no room to stow even a normal small backpack. Plus one's legs are only stretched to half the space. The seat pitch is very close even for a small person (I am 5'6"), I think the seat would be impossible for anyone over 6'. No seatback entertainment, music the old-style 10 channels, movies + NBC overhead. Surprising these are still flying over 4 hours, e.g., across Atlantic.

A newer plane. Did not care for the design. And there is literally no floor/underseat storage in business class. There’s a small pocket near the ground about 8” wide and maybe 4 “ deep. There’s an even smaller pocket next to the lie flat seat. And a magazine pocket. No video screen either.

Great legroom! 
However: The area next to the door (rows 20 and 21, seats A,B, H,J) is VERY COLD. Be sure to bring extra layers. One long sleeve sweater was not enough. The rest of the plane was warm, only we were freezing. 
(I flew this plane multiple times in row 21, I love this row.)

The missing window was not a problem, because there is a second window further forward. The seat recline was limited but OK. That whole area (rows 12-13) has a separate feeling, which is nice, seems quieter, and is not cramped. It's a GOOD seat.

After reading the previous reviews on this plan, I was very leery of our flight between PHL and Budapest.  We were in the center section, row 34.  Fortunately, we had an empty seat between us.

The plane was a bit older, but the only way to tell was the lack of seatback entertainment and the old "sky phone" at each seat.  The seats were not ripped or worn, and the lavatories were clean and in good shape.  Otherwise, the flight was smooth, on-time and as comfortable as any 9-hour flight in economy class can be.

Worst flight ever. Seat was broken and did not decline. No TV screen so told to use laptop but no power so on a 7 hour flight that was of no help. No individual air and cold air blew in my face for 7 hours and made me sick. Internet was NOT working. Overhead light was broken so I couldn't read either. Overhead luggage compartments are too small for most bags. Just torture. On return flight (259) ALL overhead lights were out. Stewardess told us that plane needed to go to a hangar to get electric fixed but AA refused to do so. Contacted AA and they told me they would give me a $25 voucher for my 7 hours of torture and that they thought that was very reasonable compensation. Do not book this flight from PHL to LIS.

I used to love the 767 for Atlantic flights . . . about 25 years ago. Today these geriatric airliners should be retired. I made the error of paying $80 for a window seat, and it turned out to have a broken reclining mechanism. So on this seven-hour overnight flight I was bolt upright with the seat in front of me right in my face. Worst flight ever, compounded by the noise (these are loud planes) and an indifferent crew. My return flight on an Airbus 330-300 was luxurious by comparison.
Very old interior. Stuff works but cant recall the last time i was in business without my own screen! They are on the ceiling.

Unbelievable cattle car ride.  These seats are so   narrow you can barely move your behind.  The pitch is so tight you can't sit a drink onto the tray table if the seat in front of you is pushed back.  This isn't air travel it is torture.  Never again on American.

We flew this plane for 8 hrs to Zurich and in this day and age, the flight was awful because you have no personal monitor to keep you entertained.  We had wifi and you could connect to AA's entertainment portal but how long will your batteries last?  The plane is 35 yrs old and although safety is not an issue here, we wish we would have done enough research to choose a different ticket.
Horrible plane, straight from the nineties: no TV screen, no power plug, mediocre food. Unworthy for today's standards.

As others have explained this is a decrepit plane, that should have been retired in the early 2000's. Plan on taking your own entertainment, power back up and food as you will get none oft his from the plane. I have to fly this route PHL to Manchester 3 times a year so I'm use to it, but its really an embarrassment. I would not pay an extra for premium economy or business as its a waste of money

This seat and the one right next to it was terrible.  The ear phone jack did not work.  The seat would not stay in a reclining position.  I agree with the reviews for this plane.  It is old, uncomfortable, and needs to be retired.  The tv monitors were every five seats with no choice but to watch what was on and it really did not matter for the audio jacks did not work.  The plane bathrooms were not kept stocked and it was an overall very negative experience vs the flight outbound on a newer AA plane.

I was moved to this seat without my knowledge after an equipment switch. This costly "Main Cabin Extra" option is the worst seat I have ever had on a full-size aircraft. Misaligned window, limited recline, bathroom adjacent, and so crammed into the corner as to induce an attack of claustrophobia. Plus overheads that are barely bigger than a commuter jet: I couldn't even get my overnight case into them.

This airplane interior is extremely old and seen better days. There were no individual TV screens and I am not sure how that inflight entertainment works on your computer! 12A and that section is probably the better more "private area" of the plane and feels ever sooo slightly like premium economy. Although row 13 C/D/E is not great at all. 

Avoid 17 A / B / H / J its like you are sitting in the area where they make the coffee. Bad. 

I was considering buying a first class ticket for this flight as I had heard it was the "flag ship" business class but very very happy I did not.

BEWARE - AA are running this relic on the MAN-PHL route "until at least Jan 2020". I was able to get MCE as part of my status but there was NO power adapter and the overhead films were rubbish. seat was OK as a bit more legroom but when we took off it sounded like bits were ready to fall off. Only 5 more trips this year on this route to get through....can't wait!

Flight in coach from Philadelphia to Zurich.  "Knee room" was average but leg room was not.  There is normally less room to put your feet in an aisle seat compared to a middle row but this was ridiculous.  There was a metal box under the seat in front of me and I believe along the entire H-row.  This left about a 15 inch wide space for my feet.  It was very difficult to get comfortable.  On top of there, there is no IFE on this aircraft unless you are in business class.  On one of the two times I got up to stretch my legs and walk around a bit on this 8-hour flight, one of the flight attendants told me I could not stand anywhere to stretch for even a few minutes and I needed to return to my seat.  By the time we landed in Zurich, I was so relieved to get off this jet!  My back and legs were cramping up from not being able to move.  Food service was average for an international flight.  I will do everything in my power to avoid flying an AA 767 again.  Just crushingly uncomfortable for a guy that is 6'3" and 170 pounds. I will probably just take a competitor's nice 787 to Europe next time.
I really think this plane was part of the TWA flight before the merger. Oldest plane I have seen in years. The biz seats look newer at least.

Terrible aircraft.  Freezing cold entire flight next to exit row door.  Pulled my jacket from overhead compartment and still freezing the entire 8+ hour trip.  Leg room was generous and comfortable in 21J.  Aircraft interior very worn.  This aircraft should be retired.

its also not enough leg room if you want to stretch your leg, since there is a wall right in front of you, its only more leg room if you keep your feet folded... also the Monitor is right above and the colors of the screen changing can bother. same with seat 20A

Flying from AMS to PHI This aircraft may quite possibly be the worst aircraft in the AA fleet.  Why are they still flying this outdated aircraft.
Seat 13J was in a dark dingy corner with no AC/DC outlet or personal IFE system.  The overhead entertainment system was not working.  
I truly think that AA uses different flight attendant for specific routs and our crew seemed to be rude at best and very unatentive leaving me to believe this was a South American rout crew flyhing overseas.
Very narrow, uncomfortable seats

Let's just say my flight PHX-PHL was way more comfortable and modern than my international 8-hour PHL-ZRH connection. Seat was cramped. I'm 5'8" and my knees practically pushed against the magazine pouch. Tried to sleep with pillow pushed into the window and arrived ZRH with back/hip ache. Controls are basic, light and call and recline buttons, dial for audio channel (to listen to the 3 movies shown on the blurred ceiling screens mounted in the center). Between my neighbor and I only one overhead light worked and we couldn't figure out who controls it. WiFi TV as described in the in-flight magazine was not available for Android.
Very outdated 1990s experience, minus the legroom in those days.

You do have extra leg room but the cold air that comes from around the emergency exit door is absolutely unbearavle.
I had to change seats in the middle of the flight and seated in a regular seat without extra leg room as I just couldn't cope with the cold.
I do not recommend this seat and probably 21J is in the same situation.

Worst “business class” ever. Dilapidated seats and tight tray tables. Entertainment is one movie on overhead screens. No GoGo inflight entertainment. Forced to buy Panasonic WiFi, which has no entertainment and too slow to stream Netflix.
Aisle seats (B) have large box (unclear what it's for) that blocks a large portion of the legroom under the seat in front.

We were in seats 13 H and J on a trip from ORD to MIA.  I do not agree that 13J is a bad seat. These were main cabin extra seats, with a little additional leg room. 13J does not line up with the window, so that's a relative disadvantage, but this row is quiet and close to the restroom but not noisy.

Seats 21 A, B, H and J are all "bucket" seats meaning they are very narrow. as your tray table is in the armrest. AA sells it at the most premium which should not be the case. Go for Row 12 instead, newer and wider seats at a cheaper price, quieter section of the plane also, though no extra legroom.

My seats 20H and J did not have almost any legroom as AA have build an extra storage for crew-blankets behind 17 H&J. We had less legroom than normal seat and paid extra. Plase was also freezing cold due to air flow from the build-in extentions seams.

Continuing from my previous review-
The seat control console is right where your arm goes when you're seating and relaxing to watch a movie after dinner. I must have unintentionaly moved my seat at least 20 times due to that poor design. Also, the IFE is on a tablet. I didn't mind it that much, coz it ment I could use my headphones without the 2 pin adapter. Also, its full HD, so watching movies was great. The crew did collect them about 30 minutes before landing.
All-in-all, one of the best flight attendents I ever had, and the plane is just old and loud. Time to retire with honor.

Flew this plane from JFK to Madrid (6.5 hours). Seat was a bit narrow and short for a big guy like me. I'm 6'2 and about 330 lbs. Couldn't sleep coz it was narrow, but seating in a relaxed position to watch a movie was really comfortable. Dinner was awesome! I pre-ordered the Filet mignon and it was amazing. Sadly, breakfast was really bad. 
Headphones are bose noise-cancelling and really good. The crew were great. My aisle was served by one of the most kind, nice, sweet and atentetive FA I've ever met. What a wonderful experience that was.
In conclusion, I can't complain to much, however, I would try to avoid this plane in the future. Same crew on the A330 or 777 would be perfect!
Virtually all the B, E and H economy seats have very large entertainment boxes under the seats filling nearly  40% of the underseat space.  It's uncomfortable finding a place for my legs there.
Unbelievable that American operates planes on intercontinental routes that have no invidual media centre (a screen in the seat in front ot you) in economy! Cmon guys!

Wow, the back of the plane is out dated while up front looks newer. I thought overhead screens had be removed years ago but AA must like them. A nice bright screen that cant be turned off on an overnight flight.

The seats in First Class are 180 degree lay flat seats with a very big pitch.  There is a lot of room for spreading out, especially true of the window seats.  2D is positioned directly onto the aisle, unlike 2A or 2G or 2J which are set in from the aisle.  So, if you are in 2D during boarding everyone walking past feels like they are on top of you.  Otherwise, I liked the seat and the plane.  It felt spacious.

It's hard to believe that American operates this flight as anything but a joke.  An 8.5 hour flight with no in-seat screens:  had the fold-down from the ceiling kind in the cabin every fifth row or so showing whatever they felt like, which was essentially a very, very, very long commercial for NBC ... it was dreadful.  I could not sleep at all on this red-eye to Amsterdam from PHL Int'l, and because I was anticipating a normal transoceanic airplane, I did not have the means to keep myself entertained for 8.5 straight hours.  The person next to me snored and drooled, which is not American's fault, but certainly less palatable with nothing to watch and/ or listen to and no ability to recline and sleep through it all.  Awful, awful flight and seat.

The seat and the plane have to officially be the worst plane and flight I have ever been on. Uncomfortable seats, cramped, insufficient recline, no entertainment- i paid for $19 internet that never worked. It's so bad- you can tell the flight attendants can't be bothered with it either. The icing on the cake was the service and food. I'm not sure what's going on here, but thhis needs to stop.
the seat is HORRIBLE! the seat in front has more room at the expense of leg room on row 30. cramped all the way. AVOID AT ALL COST

I think this may have been the best economy seat on the entire relic of a plane.  Even that could not make up for the ancient entertainment system (one screen at the front of the cabin) and limited bins space.  A/C was non existent with no personal controls, and they showed a movie that was as old as the plane itself.  Flight attendants were even lamenting about the awful conditions of the plane and wanted it retired.  Awful that AA would still have this in the fleet and worse they use it for 7 hour+ international flights.

ZRH - PHL time warp. Moved back at least fifteen years into the days of overhead video screens. Samsung tablets provided for IFE were just barely satisfactory. The seat does lie flat and is fairly comfortable, but it's pretty narrow and feels sort of like a coffin. BTW, the Philadelphia airport is awful if you have to connect to an AA domestic flight.

This is one of the most enjoyable biz class seats I've been in.  Daytime flight MAD-JFK. Great to be right be the window (even number rows).  Much less awkward than AA 777 seating.  Between the table and the shelf there is a lot of room and I had a productive workday.  Avoid the fish - it doesn't reheat well.

This seat is extremely comfortable.  Goes completely flat.  And when it is flat it is very private.  There is a lot of personal space associated with this seat.  However, if you are sitting here during boarding, there is no privacy.  It can feel awkward with everyone going by checking out your accommodations.  I like the 767 because it feels very spacious.
This row does NOT have a moveable armrest

This plane needs to be retired, simply put.  Could not believe they only had the entertainment via the early 90's era shared TV screens throughout the plane.  Very little storage space, no power, and plane smelled like urine.  I would look for alternatives and not fly this back unless you plan to sleep for the majority of the flight.

Awful, outdated equipment. Welcome to 90s-era overhead screens, group entertainment and no power in the economy section. Main Cabin Extra is a bizarre tiny gulag crammed between galleys and bathrooms. American should not be using this archaic aircraft for ling-haul routes.

The tray table IS in the armrest therefore is immobile and minimizes seat width.  This is not indicated on the map and shows the seat to be a very good seat, but this challenge is unfortunate for someone of size.  We experienced this on two different flights (N389AA and N349AN)

we had a flight from philadephia to amsterdam, flight was horrible!!!
no space at all, worst company to fly with!
We know you cannot expect comfort at a plane, but at least some hygiëne and friendly staff!

Flight went well (from BUD to PHL) and the service and food were fine. No real complaints, BUT AA does really need to retire this plane. First, there are very dated overhead TV monitors, an often not working tablet in the back of the seat in front of one's seat, the forward BC bathroom had the sink completely covered in duct tape (!?), the other bathroom had only the cold tap covered in duct tape (a pleasant change!), and the overhead light didn't work. My husband was seated in 4A and had the same problem with the overhead light. The seat cushions are a bit thin, so my hip bones felt it for the next couple of days and although I'm 5'10", no problem with stretching out to sleep.

Recently flew PHL-ZUR round trip in same seat. Very comfortable seat, got a decent amount of rest (several hours). Food was good and ample. Crew was very attentive. No problems using tablet. Minor issues: seat width is not great, could not lie flat, needed to be at an angle or on side. Amount of storage space is minimal. Would I ride again- yes.

We upgraded to "extra leg room" for our return flight from Budapest to Philadelphia because our seats on our overnight flight from Miami to London in regular economy were terribly cramped. These seats were terrible. While the leg room was fine,  the overhead lights did not work, nor did the audio volume control nor the wifi nor the flight attendant call button. One of the restrooms was out of order from the beginning.  I had brought a book to read and an ipad to watch films but could not do either. Without proper sound, forget the diversion of  overhead movies (bad as they were, perhaps selected for teenageers.)  9 and 1/2  hours in the dark in the middle of the day were totally miserable.  Never again on AA.

Just flew PHL- BUD in business class 8D.  The seat was comfortable but leg space was tight for my 6'1'' frame while in the lie flat position.   Seat 8A was reserved for flight crew rest and even has privacy curtains they deploy once in flight.  The curtains partially hang in the aisle and cause the flight attendants and passengers to brush against you in 8D.  Overhead bin space is minimal in the center section of the aircraft, but just OK on the outer bins,  That's a manageable problem for the biz class with fewer passengers, but is a bigger problem for economy.  American was offering to check carry on bags for free at the gate due to the very limited bin space.  Our food was good for both dinner (filet) and breakfast (omelette).  Service was good, but the flight attendant picked up the entertainment tablet while I was still asleep.  I had planned to watch something for the last hour of the flight but it was too late.  I was happy to have non-stop service to BUD, but the 767's are clearly showing their age.

The seat did not offer extra legroom (paying $159 extra)compared to other seats in the economy class as one cannot straighten the legs because of the separation wall with the business class. To my opinion therfore paying extra is a hoax.

American's 767's provided reasonable Economy seating for a PHL-BUD round trip. Legroom and lavatory space were adequate; the "older" style seats wide and well-cushioned; window seats good for sleeping; and 2-3-2 seating convenient for aisle access.  Unlike most reviews here, the lack of inflght entertainment at my seat was fine with me it made it easier to sleep without distraction.

12A and B are great Main Cabin Extra (MCE) seats - they're bulkhead but separated by a wall to Business Class. There are only three rows in this small mini-MCE section which make you feel separated from the noise of the Economy section. Seats were comfortable enough but there were two main problems with this flight: (1) the power was not working (note that power is a cigarette lighter adapter fitted with a USB port) and (2) no streaming movies available to watch on your own device - you are limited to watching the poor selection of movies on the overhead TV screens

Power outlet was DC ONLY! Very outdated, and when I asked for an adapter I was greeted with Scorn, as though I was supposed to have a Cigarette DC Power adapter in my carry on! My flight was from JFK to MAD, international transatlantic, and drinks WERE NOT COMPLIMENTARY.  I am platinum with AA and this was BY FAR the worst equipment - domestic or international - I have flown. Prior to boarding, make sure your electronics are fully charged, and substantially lower your expectations. Very disappointed with "American" Airlines for continuing to book this aircraft.

The seats were very comfortable in all settings and the staff was very good except for one guy who was having a bad day for some reason.  Food was OK about standard for AA and thawing list good.  The selection of movies was extensive and quite good.  My wife's video didn't work and she was compensated with miles.

I find the whiny reviews about business class to be totally unfounded. My experience on a recent flight to Montevideo was completely acceptable. Yes the aircraft is old, and yes the entertainment system consists of a tablet. So what? The movie selection was decent and headphones very good. I slept perfectly fine (I'm 6' 175#...maybe overly tall or overweight may have problems). Pick a seat with the table between you and the aisle for undisturbed sleep. My vegetarian-requested meal was actually rather tasty (surprisingly). Only minor complaint was movement of person behind, when turning around, could be felt. Am trying 8G on return, so hopefully will eliminate that problem. Service was satisfactory. Quit whining everyone...you sound like spoiled-rotten (US) Americans and it's annoying. Admittedly coach is total and utter misery, but business class gets a thumbs-up!

Overall, this is not an airplane for this day and age. The plane is old, filthy, cramped and just generally not pleasant.
Just the fact that there are still Overhead monitors, instead of in-seat entertainment for a transatlantic flight is beyond comprehension. The Wright brothers had more comfort on their first flight.
This plane is a testament of why American Airlines is going our of business, and considered one of the worst airlines in the world.

If you plan on flying the 767, here are a few helpful hints:

1.  Be under 6', 170 pounds, of medium build, and a size 10 shoe or smaller.  Anything outside those parameters will make for a less than pleasant business class seat experience

2.  Don't use the armrest on the console as that has the seat controls on it.  Not sure who designed the placement of it on the 'refreshed/improved' business class but I hope they've been summarily let go from that field of employment.

3.  The entertainment system consisting of a tablet leaves A LOT to be desired.  Awkward positioning, questionable power cord system, and flimsy construction make  for rough viewing.  Any sort of turbulence will bring it down like a house of cards.

I really wouldn't suggest that plane, or class of service, to anyone. Far from a business class experience, let alone for international travel.  Disappointing.

I registered on seat guru just to comment on this plane. this plane is so old that the arm rests still have cigarette trays. The extra leg room seats do NOT have AC power, It is DC power. And good luck asking for an adapter. Ive flown on countless flights and airlines across tne world in the last 2 weeks and i am embarassed by the service and experinece of flying American-based companies.

Very limited legroom in this "MCE" seat.  Nothing more than standard econ.  On my flight however there were only 7 people in the mini-cabin so was able to make a bed out of this row.

Beware seats in row 12 and 20.  Those arm rests don't adjust so you can't make a bed from those rows.

21B has lots of leg room but arm rest is also not adjustable, so cannot take advantage of an empty 21A.

In all, this is a terrible aircraft.  Basically no amenities to speak of.  IFE non existent.  DC (!!!!) power ports only in econ.

Flew overnight GIG-JFK on this ancient plane. Great legroom, but totally negated by the freezing temperatures around emergency exit (probably 15 degrees centigrate colder than rest of cabin). It was so bad I switched seats on the return flight.

Not a terrible hard product. Even seats along the windows have a buffer with the aisle and the bed was decent. There is no personal air and a lack of storage. Bathrooms are bigger than 787 but still small.  Food was ok, service was decent but it's a small business class. The obviously annoying feature is the lack of built in entertainment. The tablet worked great, but you get it 45 mins into a flight and give it up before landing.

Incredibly old plane, everything was dated and toilets particularly were unacceptably maintained. No in-seat entertainment (tablet handed out had a relatively good selection, but was not very responsive to touch). Although the seat was narrow, the bed was comfortable and it was possible to sleep. Food was good on this flight and the cabin crew were superb, probably because they knew they had to be to make up for the piece of junk that was the plane!

Recently experienced the absolute worst flight equipment ever (domestic or international) during an American Airlines JFK -> CDG leg. Just walking onto the aircraft was a step-back in time. The business class "entertainment system" is an early generation Samsung tablet stuck with Velcro to the seat back in front of you . . . And then the old tablet was retrieved by flight attendants prior to landing. Nevermind that most folks never got them working properly anyway (Do they REALLY think someone will abscond with the antique electronics?) Many of the power seats and/or power outlets were not in working order. I suffered a shoulder injury attempting to raise my inoperable seat to an upright position. Food service was as just bad - Whole, raw, cold, "smoked" carrots as an appetizer - Before the gray, gelatinous, "hockey puck" of a filet. A most horrible flight . . . I even felt sorry for the flight attendants because it was clear they had their own malfunctioning systems to deal with. NEVER another American Airlines international flight itinerary here.

Pros: 
-the cloth seats are comfortable
-the two-row cabin of MCE for rows 12 & 13 are quiet and private

Cons: 
-overhead IFE
-no wifi on my flight
-where there is power, it is only cigarette lighter adapter (MCE)

This is 2017. How is this plane still being used for international travel?

Finally American has upgraded their 1st class service between HNL and DFW.  After years of having to endure a tilted seat that always made you feel as though you were slipping down, they have totally upgraded first class.  The seat in first class along the windows offer the most privacy, with seat 2, 4, 6 and 8 having the most privacy since you are sitting near the window with a wide table separating you from the aisle.  No more having those awful oversize carry on bags hitting you in the head.  The meal service is not as good as it was in the past, the salad is now served with the meal.  Menu cards are handed out on occasion.  The ice cream sundae remains great.  While the seat width is not great, if you are normal sized person you can easily turn over from your back to your front.  The outdated entertainment tablets require that they are plugged into an outlet.  While the choices are very good, the time it takes to hand these units out with the Bose noise canceling earphones is ridiculous.  Time to see the entertainment center incorporated into the seat in front of you.  Overall an excellent experience for a long flight.

These are old planes. No entertainment stsyems in coach, only overhead screens. My flight to MXP was ok, there was a small box under the seat in front but the return plane is different and has a very large box under the seat in front.
Confusing since as I said there is not power or entertainment.

First class on this place is great!  Seats are fully lie-flat. 2 different charging stations. The seats along the windows are staggered. They are single with a console table area.  2, 4, 6, 8 have the seats along the windows with the console on the aisle. Seats 3, 5, 7 have the seats on the aisle with the console next to the window.  I liked the even numbered seats better - more privacy.  Great 1st class for domestic travel!
Worst flight I have ever taken.  Seat is very unconfortable and will only recline an inch or so.

I recently flew this airplane on American Airlines from JFK to Zurich and back, both in business class, and I have no idea why the reviews here are so negative for the business class portion of the plane.  I found the flight to be extremely pleasant, the service to be very good, and the business class cabin to be pretty standard.  The seat could be bigger, but in my experience, it was pretty much like other business class seats.  I sort-of liked the idea of everyone having their own tablet for entertainment... it does not have a screen with the moving airplane on it, but there is an extensive selection of movies and books on the tablet.  The only negative is that the cabin attendants collect the tablets about an hour before landing. Both my flights were extremely pleasant (I was in seat 6A on the outbound flight).

This is the worse plane I have flown on in many years. I cannot believe it is the plane AA chose for there new DFW AMS flight. It is in the exact state it was in 25 years ago.  My headphine jack volume could not be adjusted below the lodesr setting.  My husbands jack did not work at all.  This is a 10 hour flight.  The crew were great but also so disappointed that they had to fly in this relic.

Not as bad as some reviewers would have it. My wife and I were comfortable and slept well on the Raleigh-London flight. The lavatory was not a problem at all, and the coat hook on the wall behind us was very handy.

Very little legroom, much less than a standard economy seat, where you can stretch your legs out under the seat in front of you. American advertises this seat as being "Main Cabin Extra," but that is a lie. Because of the bulkhead, you cannot stretch out your legs. I chose this seat because of the "Main Cabin Extra" designation, which supposedly means extra legroom, as I get pain in my left knee if I cannot stretch out my legs. I do not appreciate being lied to. I was in pain for much of this flight.

This is the worst business class seat I have had on a wide body jet. The cabin should be gutted and rebuilt. Seat is short and crowded as a flat bed. Controls are not very good and can easily be activated accidentally. Entertainment technology is from the last century! Handed tablet but tv screens are still hanging from the ceiling.

This seat and those around me have no power outlets contrary to other information. Also, my carry-on 4-wheeled legal sized bag, that has been on dozens of flights with no problem, does not fit in the undersized overheads.
This plane is a shame. 8 hours with no entertainment and minimal seat pitch. I am not particularly tall but still could not fit in the seat. A plane to avoid.
This seat has no storage beneath the seat in front of it. My husband is 6' tall and has size 11 feet and had nowhere to put his feet other than in the aisle or the space in front of 31A.
Finally have wifi on the 767-300.  Panasonic wifi just like the 777 and 787.  Also version 2 of the 767 is now the most common version.  There are very few version 1 configurations left.

These Business class seats - currently called First when flying domestically - are nice. I just flew JFK-MIA and wanted to correct some info I believe was misstated elsewhere here. There is no Row 1. The section has 28 lie flat seats in seven rows 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. There's a good photo on this Seatguru page dated 9/16/14 that shows the biz cabin configuration I just flew. There are eight excellent "A" and "J" window seats in rows 2, 4, 6, 8. Those in rows 3, 5, 7 are ok but directly on the aisle. Row 7 is missing one of two windows others have. Two people traveling together will like the D and G pairs in the center. Alternately, a couple may like the G & J aisle seats in rows 3, 5, 7. Happy travels!

I am 6'5", about 220lbs and this is the worst business class seat.  Let's not even bother calling it first class.  On a 7 hour flight, and you do not have snacks for the pax?  Yeah, you aren't first class.

The bed is too short to use.  With my head all the way against the wall I had to have my knees bent to even get the seat flat. comfortable with a lot more options for how to adjust the seat.

Just avoid these old planes.

This plane looks quite old. No space for the legs and hardly any recline. No personal entertainment system in eco which is a real problem for a 7-hours flight and no power supply on the seat. The food was totally scary, especially at breakfast. I will make sure I never fly AA again, this company stayed in the 90s and there's competition.

In general these "Business Class" seats are subpar, with limited legroom when fully flat, and are very narrow.  Also your head is adjacent to the arm rests in this position and you may feel like you're in a small box. While the seat lacks width, the ridiculously large adjacent desk space takes up the remaining room immediately to your right... they should have made the seat wider!  Also no in seat entertainment... the old style portable tablets are passed out.  This class of service is in dire need of a redesign and upgrade!

This is a crew rest area on long haul night flights, and will be surrounded by a heavy curtain, so be aware if you are seated in front (7A) or adjacent in row 8 of this activity. In general these "First Class" seats are subpar, with limited legroom when fully flat, and very narrow.  Also your head is adjacent to the arm rests in this position and you may feel like you're in a small box.

This is a crew rest area on long haul night flights, and will be surrounded by a heavy curtain, so be aware if you are seated in front (7A) or adjacent in row 8 of this activity. In general these "First Class" seats are subpar, with limited legroom when fully flat, and very narrow.  Also your head is adjacent to the arm rests in this position and you may feel like you're in a small box. While the seat lacks width, the ridiculously large adjacent desk space takes up the remaining room immediately to your right... they should have made the seat wider!  Also no in seat entertainment... the old style portable tablets are passed out.  This class of service is in dire need of a redesign and upgrade!

On the updated American Airlines 767-300 with 8 rows of business/first class, the odd-numbered A and J seats are actual window seats with aisle access. The even-numbered A and J seats are technically aisle seats, as the console is located between the window and the seat. This places the seat directly on the aisle. For overnight flights and during boarding, this can result in people bumping into you when walking down the aisle.

Flew from JFX to MXP overnight trip so the added leg room was nice to have.  Only negatives: overhead bin space is very limited and small for a jumbo jet.  Second the plane we had was the old swing open style of lavatory door (versus the accordion style which is more common now) so every time the door closed it was loud against the seat.
There is no floor storage in this seat. Version 2 of AA 767-300. The power requires an AC adapter (cigarette lighter type)
Seat 3A in the AA B767-Ver. 2 has the desk between the seat and the window, making access to looking out the window a little more difficult than in the

I flew MIA-MVD a couple of nights ago on one of the 763s in this configuration (reg: N389AA) and I was pleasantly surprised. 1) The aircraft was 22 years old but the whole cabin and even toilet was immaculate. Must have been fresh from heavy maintenance - goes to show how this can cloak aircraft age. 2) The seat was more comfortable than anticipated. If not for snoring passenger one row behind, could have slept most of the flight. 3) As a bonus, AA service was quite decent and food just about edible. Very different to my AA 763 experiences in the past. A point for SeatGuru: row 13 is missing a window on both sides.
This flight from DFW to Honolulu was very good. The flight attendants were superb!

All the seats in Biz have A/C power ports and all the seats in Main Cabin Extra are still DC/Car charger power ports, on long haul flights, they carry a few converters, so ask nicely and you might be able to get one.

In the 763 V2 Business Class, with 1-2-1 row format, the Even numbered D seats are hard on the aisle, with a smaller width table than the G seat (9 inch difference?).  The G seat has its table next to the aisle, giving you a touch more privacy.  The Even numbered A seats sit next to the window with table on the aisle, the Even numbered J seats are on the aisle with the table next to the window.  Odd numbered seats are reversed.  All still better than the old V1 2-2-2 format.

During the flight rows 20-22 were EXTREMELY COLD. Passengers doubled up on blankets, literally wore winter clothing with hats, hoods, and gloves AND the flight attendants passed out HOT WATER bottles to passengers. They said it is ALWAYS cold over the wings and exit rows (that we paid extra for).

Finally, American has some fully flat seats in business.  A noticeable drawback, however, is the the cubby hole for your feet in the bed position leaves no room to move your feet around as you are attempting to sleep. Also, the food on this flight was below par, even for economy.

Once again, AA switched the plane on us in Dallas.  Reason---mechanical.  This is the third trip in a row in which this has happened.  Instead of 1-2-1 seating, it's a very old 2-2-2 First/Business class seating with angle lie flat beds.  Absolutely no way anyone is going to be able to exit his/her seat if it is a window.  There isn't one inch of space between the aisle seat and the unmoveable arm rest.  Service and food were good, but this is a joke of a plane for and 8 1/2 hour flight.  IFE system was good, and there was a nice selection of movies from which to choose

First time flying American Airlines. Great experience from check in to landing. Check in staff very efficient no problems and minimal waiting. Boarding usual order passengers with children or who needed help , followowed by business class passengers etc. Very attentive flight attendants a couple if glasses of champagne. Entertainment business class passengers are given a samsung tablet and Bose headphones, a good selection of tv / movies. Not sure how passengers who do not used tablets would of got on.Seat good, plenty if leg room and adjustment of the seat, I did not try the lay flat option a minor niggle the seat control panel is very sensitive so sometimes you would accidently move the seat if you rested you elbow on the panel. Food great I was able to select sone if the food online. Would definetley fly American again

The seat converted into a flat bed but this was the only plus point about this flight. The plane was grotty and very shabby - I felt dirty within minutes of sitting down.  There was no storage at the seat and no privacy screen between myself and the seat next to me. As others have said, the plane was old and had the look and feel of something from the 1970s. My recommendation: AVOID at all costs. It's not worth anything like the £4k that my seat cost. Not special or luxurious like other airlines. The amenity bag looked cheap and was comparable to what economy passengers get on other flights.  Even though I had boarded at 9.45pm there had been no option to eat before boarding so that we could sleep on the flight.

Travelling from JFK to CDG this 767 was a bit of a downgrade as our flight to JFK some weeks earlier was in one of the refurbished 777-200's. I already knew these seats Finnair that uses similar seats in their A330's. Awkward table and Samsung tablets for entertainment. Nevertheless I had some excellent sleep on this short (6:30) flight.
This is an old and inconvenient  airplane. No space in bins

You may think you are just going from Point A to Point B, but you get something extra as this plane (in Economy or MCE) is also a time machine. It allows you to travel as people did in the 80s, without the higher quality meals or service. Old bathrooms, no power, no video screens except the big clunky tvs hanging from the ceiling. Pretty cool, right? If you disagree, do not fly this bird unless your in business...even then, it should be really be the cheapest Biz ticket between your destinations.

I am frequent traveler and this plane was big surprise. If I know I will  never book this flight. It is very old plane, uncomfortable seats, no space for carry on bags at all,so small overhead bins. Worst part is entertainment, no TV unit in front seat, most boring and long flight ever had.
Staff on my side was very nice and helpful.

Oldest plane in the fleet!! 
No legroom, air, or video screens.
This plane should not be used for overseas flights for 9 hours, which it currently is. They hand out newspapers because they know you will need it in hour 4 of 9.
I was at the bulkhead seat in 12A, so this was certainly a 767-300 v2 layout, but the power was DC, not AC as noted on the page.

My family flew from New York to Zurich and back! My dad was a staff for American so he booked a staff ticket for just $0 and me and my mother was part of his buddy pass! First thing I wanted to address about this standby ticket was that we always have to dress up in business clothes! I'm tired of sticking to business clothes! My dad tried to book a business class ticket for the 3 of us. Flight 64 did not have any available BC seats from NY to Zurich so we sat on Economy. Not what I was expecting, no Personal IFE, bit crampy seat, and stuff! My seat was 32J so the only thing I was glad about is the food service and the window seat! I have to face 7 hours or boredom and being cramped overnight! I had trouble sleeping. We also had a return back to NY with BC seats! It was good, the only thing I hate about is not being seated on the window section, but we were in the front! My seat is 2H. It was an amazing experience thanks to the personal Samsung Galaxy Tab provided by the airline. My dad always go for American first when we book trips to Europe or any other country that American flies to. But I will not choose American if I do not fly with a personal IFE! If I had the chance to make a suggestion about the 763 on American, I tell em to put a personal IFE and a power outlet on every seat (including the Economy Cabin), or don't use the 763 on any flights over 3 hours! That's all I have to say! BTW, I think I do know that Delta can be a good alternative from ZRH to JFK, even though it uses the 763! The aircraft 763 is cool though, but google flights showed me that Delta could have Wi-Fi on there, and one thing I like is that it had power outlets and a personal IFE! If you get a 763 on an American to locations over 3 hours, choose Delta, the second cheapest airline!

This plane, except for the revamped Business Class, is a real old bucket of bolts. Avoid this seat. This seat is less than 3 feet from the Lavatory door, which opens facing forward so you get the "waft of lovely lavatory air" every time the door is opened, which is pretty much all night. The flushing sound is so loud you cannot possibly sleep through it. When the seat in front is fully reclined (as this is a Business Extra seat with supposed extra leg room) you cannot have a laptop opened on the tray table, making it impossible to watch any entertainment on your own device, which is necessary, since the affor mentioned "old bucket of bolts" does not offer ANY VOD at the seat for an 8+hour flight from ORD to CDG. Pretty rediculous on AA's part.

AA should retired all OLD B767-300 like the aircraft I flew. As American, I felt embarrassed when I aboard this aircraft because I heard most foreigners said "Oh my gosh" about the aircraft. Especially flew from/to Zurich, home one of the richest people in the world.

Flew JFK to MAN in seat 12J. seat is extra narrow as the tray table is in the arm rest. I'm 6 foot 3. bulkhead allows for room but you can't stretch your legs out as they hit the bulkhead. Only good seats on this plane are 21B and 21H. About 2 feet of leg room. 21A and 21J have great room but the side wall restricts you shoulder

Flew this plane from MAN to JFK. For a business class seat it is really a poor design. At 20 inches it is narrow for business class. Although your lower body is comfortable your shoulders are wider than the seat will allow. Seat controls are located where your elbow rests so the seat is constantly self adjusting. Window even number seats are better than odd number seats as they are next to the side wall. Odd seats are next to the isle where the cart bumps you and wakes you up. Entertainment is a tablet with nothing much to watch. Really annoying design. Other than food and drink, business class on this aircraft is not worth the price. On a positive 2J has 3 windows.
Window looks over wing motor, blocking view. Prefer 2j or 6J because seat is closer to window, and not on isle
HORRIBLE. No Personal IFE, old plane, tiny aisle. flight attendants were rude. not helpful at all. Never again.

Watch out for AL'S current seat games on HNL flights. Booked my flight and seat 4A 8 months in advance, and then three weeks before flight, I receive an e-mail stating there had been a flight change. No notice that the seat configuration was changing from 2-2-2 to 1-2-1, and our two window/  aisle seats were changed to a center and window seat, so we were seated across an aisle.  They could only then give us bulkhead seats.  On the day of flight 5/21/16, we boarded only to find the aircraft was the old configuration. Instead of returning our original window/aisle seats, they kept us in the center bulkhead seats. Our friendly FA stated seating was not her department.  Same issue on our return flight on 6/10, so apparently AA'S planning and website cannot be trusted. The couple behind us had a similar experience, and the only consistency was the FA'S response that seating was not her problem.  Apparently Useless Air's service level has transferred over to the AA livery.

As stated before, even numbered aisles are the best for window seating.  Flew this equipment from PHL to ZRH on 20 May - I have to say it was the best service I've had on AA - I was lucky enough to have the lead flight attendant (Stefan, I believe) serving my side of the cabin.  Fantastic.  Seats are fine - I didn't find the touch screen for the seat controls a big deal.  However, the in flight entertainment is an atrocity.  It takes the crew 30 minutes to hand out the tablets, and then they collect them an hour before landing (or sneak them away while you are sleeping, which is what they did to me).  I will admit I don't watch too much on an overnight flight, but it's nice to watch a TV show or something.  My plea to AA would be to bring these planes into the 21st century  with some decent IFE kit - I am a loyal AA flyer so won't say that I will fly other airlines - but when I fly on an Air Canada commuter jet that has built in IFE on a flight from YYZ to PHL and an AA widebody doesn't have it, I begin to wonder.  Happy flying.
The business class from Zurich to JFK was wonderful.  Lots of room and very comfortable seats. This new modern arrangement is a great improvement over the prior configuration.

I'm pleased to report American is now using this plane for it's DFW to OGG service.  The seats were outstanding and the service was great.  The complaints I've read of others about this plane's first class service is unreasonable at best.  Actually looking forward to our return flight after a great time in Maui.

My partner and I flew the LHR-ORD on flight 87 we were in seats 13A and 13B. The seats are narrow but the leg room is good (see uploaded photos) only drawback is there is a box in front of 13B foot area so you have to stretch your legs to the left a bit to get them fully stretched. Seats are a bit narrow but arm rest does raise, its a bit tricky to get the aisle arm rest to raise but it can be done. Proximity to the lavatories wasn't a problem for us.  There are no seat back TV's on this flight and the persons in 12A and 12B tend to block the TV's with their heads; so I would suggest bringing an iPad or something similar to watch.

Exit Isle seats shouldn't be allowed to recline!  They have all the leg room and yet were able to recline their seats practically into our laps! Absolutely rediculous on a long flight from the States to Hawaii nd back.

I flew this plane from MIA-SCL and back. It was a hellish travel experience. First, this aircraft is like something out of the distance past in air travel. If the flight had a smoking section, it would not have seemed out of place. For starters, I noticed that Business Class did not have individual video monitors! Note to self: NEVER waste money to fly C class on this plane. Unbelievable in this day in age.
On my flight to Santiago, I was in 38A. I felt like I was being flown to Guantanamo Bay and kept in a "stress position" for the entire flight the seat was so cramped. They served a meal - when the flight attendant asked what I wanted for dinner, I said "More space", and then I dropped the tray table to show him that there wasn't enough room for it to fold down all the way. Seriously. Who permits planes like this to be so cramped? I know if we had crashed landed, I would certainly burned to death as there is no way I could have extracted myself in enough time.
My flight back in 13C was marginally better. While there was much more legroom (thankfully) I agree with the this seat being mark yellow on Seat Guru -- and I could argue it should be red. The horrid sewer smell from the lavatory over my left shoulder was disgusting. The person in 13G was father from me than the toilet! DISGUSTING!
I will never willingly fly on American in this aircraft again. The only reason I did this time was because I was required to use a government contract fare. Next time I will do whatever it takes to avoid using AA or I won't make the trip.  A HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE.

My husband and I flew this plane from CDG-ORD.  The seats were comfortable and it was nice to have aisle access from any seat.  The service and food were fine.  I agree with the other commenters regarding even number seats.  My husband kept getting bumped by the carts and other passengers as they were boarding.  On this flight everyone took the same path and had to walk thru the Business cabin to get to their seats.  But a  minor complaint for such vastly improved comfort over Economy.
Power supply is the DC outlet (cigarette lighter style adapter needed) for all MCE seats. 1 per pair of seats, positioned below the armrest.

I don't know what all the complaining about business class is for.  I upgraded my seat for my first leg home (Zurich to JFK) and it was really comfortable with tons of room and lots of places to stash stuff.  I'm glad I followed a prior passenger's advice to take the even numbered seats as this eliminates the aisle bumping.  The staff was friendly, the food okay, and the entertainment device was fine.  I know AA has taken space away from the main cabin in all their planes, but if you're fortunate enough to get (or pay for, in my case) an upgrade, enjoy it. It's great. My only negative was no wifi. I would expect AA to have wifi on all planes these days. I know it's not an "over water" thing because I had wifi the whole way out to London.  It's not hard or expensive to retrofit even an older plane with wifi, so AA should just do it. I believe it's a profit center for them.  Anyway, no complaints.  The lack of wifi enabled me to enjoy my seat more.
Seat is fine. The compartments for carry on luggage are extremely tiny. Do not bring carry on roller. Just small gym bags.
Rows 2, 4, 6, and 8 singles are the best. The table is on the aisle providing privacy.  If in the middle even G or odd D are preferred with larger tables and more cozy space.

I flew on this plane in both domestic J (First) and international Y (coach). I rather liked the seats in First; they are comfortable and would be excellent for a long haul flight. I'm 6'2" and while the configuration when lying flat isn't perfect (you have to do some contortion to fit well), it's better than coach. In coach, 21H is one of the better seats. It has extra legroom, at the cost of narrower seats (although not too narrow) and poor foot space. The lack of personal in-flight entertainment is a huge knock against this aircraft however. If it's a day time flight, bring your own entertainment or you'll be bored and uncomfortable.

middle seats in the business class cabin are perfect for passengers traveling together, if you're traveling alone, you will endure very little privacy.

agree with other posts, that the even number window seats afford the most privacy as the tray table is on the aisle side, putting the seat closer to the window.

odd numbers, as stated by previous posts have the seat on the aisle side.  not as private.

seat was very comfortable, in the sleep fully flat position.  no mattress pad provided.  

decent selection of movies from IFE, however, not a fan of the portable players.

service seemed rushed.  also, tablets and headphones were collected early, probably due to the fact that nearly everyone was asleep, kinda sneaky.

overall acceptable trans-atlantic option.

These seats are sooooooo cold it feels like your legs and feet are outside the aircraft.
Very, very poor seats and still too much money for this type of seat.

Seats with aisle access have more leg room than others. It varies depending on row and whether window or aisle. Suggest SG to more accurately define these J class seats.  5A (left side)has tray on left side thus more leg room when fully reclined. 7J(right side) has tray on left side and legs are greatly restricted when seat fully reclined. Like putting your legs into a tube. Unable to bring knees up when sleeping on side. See picture #9 as example.

Row 7 seats A & J only have one window right by the seat.  Other seats in the cabin have two windows.  Overhead bin space above middle rows very limited, and seatback entertainment removed from domestic flights.

I found this seat a little bit narrow, and the seat controls are always involuntarily activated by my arm, so, the seat needs to be configured often.  However, i believe that it is a nice seat and the aisle access is great for all  in business class

Agree about Odd number seats.  They are misaligned and I had one window and 8J had windows that were right behind my seat that I had to ask to close.  Tray table are from another world, whoever designed did not think of the passenger.  On the way TO europe I got upgraded on BA and was amazing. I got upgraded to this seat and as much as I want to be proAA was so very, very sadly disappointed.  Even number seats are the way to go ONLY and even then, you can't sleep. It's so narrow you can barely turn over.  For a transAtlantic... barely, barely passable for business. DEFINITELY not first class.

The even# seats are window which is good. Allows for more personal space. Overall seat satisfaction is average.
No place for floor storage since the foot areas slope down and back. The tables are a bit quirky and difficult to use. The F/A needed help to close it. The seat adjustment controls are place right where I place my wrists and hands. This means the seat is constantly adjusting. Poor design. The worst aspect of the experience is the laptops. For the $monies expended AA missed the boat by not doing the complete job and build in the entertainment systems. Poor decision!
"Penny wise & pound foolish" Basically a halfway upgrade!

Very very poor legroom.  Anyone over 5'7" should not sit in row 12.  I disagree with row 13 being yellow, i think that row should be green and row 12 yellow or red.  No noise or bother from the restrooms behind 13.  Mini cabin is quite nice.

A big improvement from AA's previous Business Class 767 product.  The lie-flat seats are a huge plus, and the all-aisle access is awesome.  A handy work table is placed next to every seat, making storage of small personal items very easy.  Samsung Galaxy Tablets are given out to all Business Class passengers.  These are alright, but I'd prefer personal TVs, as the Tabs don't have moving maps.  But, all-in-all, a fantastic seat!

The aircraft really old, the walls were not white they were grey with darker grey spots. The toilets were old and dirty.
The food was below average and the wine collection poor.
A week before I flew EK in C-Class between DXB and DUS what a difference. We passengers should complain  about American and European carriers and not them about the Arabian carriers.
AA never again

I appear to be in the minority, but I like this J cabin seating, with a few caveats. To me, the seats feel fairly spacious, with plenty of niches to store small items within easy reach. There are two universal AC outlets (the one by your shoulder also has a USB port), and a pretty good amount of real estate for setting your various belongings in flight. Plenty of legroom (I'm 6'-1) and elbow room. 2J does not have overhead storage due to equipment above the seat, but I had no problems finding room in the bin behind or across from the seat.

As mentioned above, even-numbered seats on the windows, and odd-numbered seats in the middle offer the most "seclusion", as the wide armrest is on the aisle. The other seats put you closer to the aisle where you will get bumped by boarding passengers.

The caveats: the tray table requires an engineering degree to understand how it deploys (I *have* an engineering degree and it took me a bit). You have to be sitting fairly upright to swing it into position (and being on the slim side will help as well), and once deployed it doesn't have the range of front-to-back travel that most other tray table configurations have; it's more that it rotates around a pivot). That said, the size was reasonable, and there is a small table that folds down from the front of the "pod" that is a good size for a tablet, freeing up some space on the tray table during meal service.

The most annoying thing is the seat control; it's a touchscreen placed *precisely* where you will lean your arm, resulting in frequent unintended set adjustments. Eventually, I learned to place a thin book or magazine over the controls to prevent accidental activation. Additionally, it seemed like the controls that operate specific parts of the seat would randomly not work; I usually moved the seat using the pre-sets and just stoping when it was close enough.

Can't comment on the seat as a bed; didn't use it as such.

There's no IFE at the seat, so you'll get the frequently-flaky Samsung tablets.

Booked our flight with US Airways ended up being code shared to AA instead.  Cant believe American Airlines still operate these planes. Flew from Manchester UK to Chicago, with a tv directly above my head, but the next tv too far away. I guess we have become so used to Airbus 330's with seatback entertainment it was like stepping back in time to the 1990's. Really dreadful on a long flight. Wont be flying AA again.

Well, I had this seat on this new plane going from ORD-CDG and it was amazing. The flight attendant asked me my name and remembered it for the whole flight. The new Business Class is a big step up from the old one. My parent was traveling for business a lot and got stuck in the old V1 and she said it was awful and cramped. This new Business Class is a big step up and I love all the personal space it gives you. Yes, I was on the aisle side, but that didn't bother me. On the way back, there was a big difference on quality, because when I was coming back, I had the V1, and it was as cramped as my parent said it was. This is a big step forward American, so please keep going forward!

I flew with my wife and 4 yr old and 10 month old JFK-MAD and chose row 13 rather than 20 (bassinet/bulkhead option) because the armrests are immovable in 20. Our 4 yr old could then lay on one of our laps in row 13. There was only DC power in this cabin on my aircraft, so be advised to bring the correct adapter! Also note that close location to the bathroom is a factor. Most flyers 'slam' the door shut and this can be trying! The bathroom door on the left side of our aircraft opens so that the light shines into MCE rather than the galley. Otherwise A/V needs to be upgraded to on demand. While I'm not a fan of Iberia, their new A330-300 planes have options to offer that top my AA 767 experience.

These are terrible business class seats.  Very narrow, tray tables are on a hair trigger (when not broken which they often are) and no in seat entertainment.  AA should fire the person that selected these seats
It was a normal economy seat. However, there is a tv right over seat 29 E, so be warned

Although the upgraded business product is much improved over the old business product, the plane is still old.  The new business class had about 30% of the seats with inoperable tray tables.  My seat had a working tray table, but like others, the table kept popping out throughout the flight.  Just touch the edge of the table and it ejects from the storage area and pops out into your lap/leg if you're sleeping.  For those without working tray tables, passengers were balancing trays of food on their laps for the meal services; definitely NOT a premium product.  Also, this particular plane did not have working inflight power so the Samsung tablets were not handed out.  Makes for a LONG 10+ hour flight without any kind of entertainment at all.  Advice: bring a fully charged device with a couple movies if you would like to watch something other than the seat back for 10 hours!

I would change 2J to yellow or green/yellow - there is no overhead storage available, as it is taken up by emergency equipment.  Luckily the crew let me put my bags in the closet which is right in front of 2J.  I really like this plane especially for domestic trips, but am confused why they didn't use the same seating and entertainment as the new 777s.  There are no individual AVOD screens, the audio controls are in a panel that you have to reach around to access, and you almost need an engineering degree to figure out the tray table.  Other than that, it is a huge improvement over the old 767 configuration and very nice to stretch out without anybody climbing over you.

I went on this plane from MXP to JFK. Plane is horrible. Only 1 meal on this 8 hour flight. No entertainment except for a few overhead screens and you only watch 2 movies because the crew rest in the middle of the flight. No legroom and width.

Worse Busiess Class seat ever, if your table is on window side of seat get ready to get hit by everything and everone in the aisle. Seat width is awful, blanket is plastic. I am a 3 million mile American Flyer and this is my end of flying American
Flew MIA-SCL on this seat. Loved the fact that the seat itself is closer to the window and the console separates it from the isle, which is good for when sleeping. Nice space and amenities.

My first experience yesterday with the updated 763.  In a couple of words...cramped and cheezy.  No seat pitch at all and your legs end up in a black hole.  Bed close to flat but the entire experience was like what I imagine being in a coffin would be.  Tray table kept popping out unexpectedly, had to twist and turn to use storage and the work area...can't believe I'm saying this but the old angled beds in the pods were perferable.  If Spirit had business class, it would look like this.

Select a window seat in even rows for more privacy Armrest and work area are on aisle side
and passenger is closest to window.
