Very comfortable for seating but the lie flat is fairly hard and tight if you are over 6 ft . Lots of video entertainment choices but the wired remote still screams 1998.  Service was exceptional going over, on par with foreign airlines i have flown. Coming back it was stereotypical - tenured flight attendanta who acted annoyed you were there.

19Feb17, 24B:  Pro:  Plenty of leg room as this is an exit row.  Cons:  The seat  feels much narrower than the 777 or even 763.  The IFE is stored next to the seat, which was slightly problematic, but the tray table was of greater concern.  It leaned to one side, so I had to hold my meals to prevent wearing them.  
I would not book 24A because the aircraft door juts in a little and limits space.  Typical AA food and drink service and the FA's were friendly.  One of them told me she didn't like the 789 because there was little food prep space in the galleys.
First time trying american premium economy cabin and absolutely loved it. Bulkhead seats have full foot rest.very specious and nice seat. Has a little storage area under the armrest.
Nice seat however did not like the fact that table was under the tv and both tv and the table were not move able so not very comfortable to sleep when half of the body is under the table/tv set

I always choose American Airlines im my trips to US. My records show more than 1 million miles in AA
This new 787 is one of the worst planes i have travelled. The seats are narrow and closer to the front chair. Finally a comment: The plane is new but the passenger is not American firt choice.

I had the opportunity to fly on AA 963 on November 14 from DFW to GRU (Guarulhos - Sao Paulo, Brazil), the equipment was a Boeing 787-900 with AA's new International Premium Economy class. The aircraft went into service on this route on November 3, so it had been operating less than two weeks on this route.

Upon boarding, a shrink-wrapped plastic bundle was waiting on each Premium Economy seat; it contained a fleecy blanket, pillow with patterned paper pillowcase, over-the-ear headphones, and an amenity kit consisting of a felt envelope containing an eye mask, ear plugs, disposable socks, and compact toothbrush/toothpaste. If you unwrap all of it, there isn't really anyplace  to put it other than shoved next to you in the seat or under you in the seat.

Mine was the first flight for many of AA's flight attendants on this plane. They were unfamiliar with the class of service and AA's intentions for the cabin. They were also unfamiliar with how to deploy bulkhead-row infotainment screens and how the seats controls are meant to work.

Probably because of the flight attendants' unfamiliarity with the plane, cadence of service was off.  The flight attendants were hand- carrying a lot of items from the rear galley to the forward galley which is immediately ahead of the Premium Economy cabin (between Premium Economy and Business Class). I overheard discussion that some food/beverage wasn't catered to the correct galley. 

After what seemed like an eternity, we got snack/drink service, though the snack was delivered and drink order taken, but it took about 10 min for my gin and tonic to arrive (and it arrived without the gin). Immediately thereafter dinner arrived- no time to enjoy my cocktail before dinner. When dinner was served, it came with a wine glass on the tray, but no offer of wine was made (and indeed, the wine I did finally get was poured into a plastic cup instead of being poured into the wine glass on my tray).  The dinner was all on porcelain dinnerware, except for the hot entree which was served in a plastic disposable tray. The meal itself was OK- at least the food on the real plates. There was a prawn cocktail, green salad, and lemon cake for dessert. The main had the typical "Chicken or Pasta?" options; the chicken in the disposable I chose tray was typical back-of-the-plane fare. 

Cadence of service was off at breakfast service (60 min before arrival) too- the food preceded the drinks cart by 15 min. Breakfast consisted of fresh fruit, a warm cinnamon bun, and some yogurt. I'll give a dishonorable mention to the coffee served with breakfast- it was truly terrible, to the point of being undrinkable brown fluid. It tasted like the inside of the plastic pitcher from which it had been poured. 


Some comments on the cabin itself - it's just 3 rows of 2-3-2 configuration (rows 9-11); each seat has its own video screen (larger than economy), its own armrests (one of which contains a tray table, the other has storage and a mains outlet for charging devices). At the bulkhead, the leg/footrests were great and legroom was good, though the leg rest is too short to support my long legs properly. The seat width was appreciated, and very noticeable when walking back through the economy cabin to use the lavatory. The seat's headrest is adjustable, and it has flaps on each side to support the head for napping, though the 15% max seat recline isn't enough to really get comfortable.


There is a lav-occupied indicator on the bulkhead at front of cabin, for the two lavatories immediately ahead of the cabin. But the Flight Attendants repeatedly told us that those lavatories were only for business class passengers only - so why is there a signal about their availability in our cabin? Our cabin is to be using the lavatories in Economy, behind row 23.

There is a curtain at the row 9 bulkhead to separate business class (and its galley/lavatories) from premium economy. But the FAs constantly came thru the curtain; the curtain was always brushing my legs in seat 9H throughout the 9h30m flight.  it was incredibly irritating- why bother closing the curtain if they're constantly going to be ducking under it?

While on the flight I watched the movie "A Bigger Splash" - it was utterly bizarre, both boring and irritating, but it had the line "Premium economy- sounds like a pen for dirty animals". Made me chuckle. Inflight entertainment options were actually pretty good on AA's system; in addition to that move I was able to watch Absolutely Fabulous the Movie; Bad Moms, Crazy Stupid Love, and Spy with Melissa McCarthy. 

My trip home on AA 962 on November 18 came at the end of a very long day. I worked all day, leaving the office in Sao Caetano at 5:30 PM; the taxi ride to the airport took 90 minutes. The 10:55 PM departure meant several hours to spend in the Admirals Club, which was fine. Boarding was a bit confused due to "Priority AAcess" never being called, but there was still room for my rolling bag and backpack overhead from my bulkhead Seat 9L.  

Upon sitting down, I was handed a Premium Economy dinner menu- that had been missing on the flight down. The dinner entree choices were Salmon or pasta.  On a plane out of São Paulo? Damn straight I chose pasta. 

Once underway, there was no cocktail service; the drink offered was what I wanted to drink with dinner. Once again I got wine in a plastic cup, then was handed a dinner tray with a wineglass on it. 

Even the pasta entree came on a real plate this time... and it looked pretty and tasted amazing. Really. Also on the meal tray were a very nice meat/cheese plate, and green salad, a roll with butter, and a cake.

Breakfast was served about an hour before arrival; it was yogurt, a warm roll, and what was probably the freshest, tastiest fruit I've ever had on an airplane. I skipped the coffee this time around.

Overall AA's Premium Economy class is an upgrade from Economy (and even Main Cabin Extra), and is better than the EVA and BA Premium Economy cabins I've flown in the past 18 months (largely because the plane is newer, so has chargers and large in-flight entertainment display screens). While nowhere near business class levels of comfort, the Premium Economy cabin makes the long-haul flight more bearable!

Seat 10D is in the new Premium Economy class.  Those seats are nice, but the legroom  is no better than that of Main Cabin Extra.  The foot-rests of seats on rows 10 and 11 are a joke.  Ridiculous.  They are just a small support for the feet (I am 6'2"and if I used them my feet would just be pushed up) whereas row 9 has a real foot/leg rest that unfolds forward from underneath the seat .  The trays ara all in the armrests, which are bulky and do not retract up.  So if you are next to an empty seat, you will not be able to stretch to the side (you would be better off in Main Cabin Extra without anyone sitting next to you).  The economy seats on this plane are very narrow (both economy and main cabin extra).  Premium Economy seats are wider.  But seatbacks do not recline much more than those of economy or main cabin extra.  Besides not having the tray on the back of the seat in front, the storage compartment (with magazines, barf bags etc) is rigid.  You cannot put even a small bottle of water there.  Food is OK.  The lighting scheme inside the 787 is interesting, but American does not darken the cabin enough.  You need eye shades if you like a dark environment to sleep.  I did not feel the "moister" cabin atmosphere that has been advertised for this plane.

Flew MAD-DFW. Great seat - tons of cubbies and storage, intuitive controls and great lighting.  Best seats in business cabin are window seats (A or L in rows 3-6). Lavs are just ok - nothing special and no amenities beyond soap.  Also, location for biz class pax is awkward.   You cannot access a lav without going through a galley.  Otherwise - a great improvement on the 787-8

Flew LAX-DFW. This seat offers outstanding leg room and knee room. I'm 6'6" and could not reach the bulkhead with my fully outstretched legs. As an exit row seat, it is slightly narrower than your typical coach seat, but not irritatingly or painfully so (AA's new A321 exit rows are the industry leader in excruciating narrowness, in my opinion). The flight attendant does sit directly in front of you for takeoff and landing, but there is so much room that it still doesn't feel cramped. Only real drawback is that the window is slightly misaligned due to the exit door, so don't expect to get great views out of those large and lovely 787 windows.

privacy = none in the middle seats , you can open some cabin divisories , but still some heavy eye and tv contact , that may botter some people. Go for the windows seats. They have a better privacy. If you are used to the 787-8 , this is way better, but I'm still a fan of the 777-3 BC

Row 18 is directly over the wings. Windows are offset. The seats are a little too firm for my taste, and the legroom is pretty tight. DON'T drop anything or you'll have a really hard time retrieving it.

Flew LAX to DFW and they finally got the bizz class seats right,  after the junk in the 787-8. All forward facing, no control console blocking the fantastic windows,  and just incredibly better.  Too bad they most likely will not update the 788s.  Also I sat for a bit in MCE in second row.  2-3-2 wide seats are great and I would have stayed there happily had they not moved me up front.  Too bad we'll never see a 789 on my normal SAntiago to LAX route.

I flew on a one-week-old 787 from LAX to DFW. The pilot said these were shakedown flights before the aircraft began flying routes from the U.S. to the far east. Like others, I found the seat to be quite narrow and the fuselage of the aircraft encroached into my seat's headspace. Unlike others here, I found the aisle was no narrower than main cabin aisles in other aircraft and the seat cushion did not tilt up enough to notice, even though I was paying attention to it. I liked the electronic window shades because they allow you to cut down on extreme sunlight while still being able to see outside. The seat-back IFE worked perfectly. The extra leg room of MCE was great. the lack of IFE boxes under the seats was a welcome surprise because I always have a bag to put under the seat in front of me. I really liked having individual air vent and light controls at my seat, something I miss on some 777s. Unfortunately, when we landed at DFW the ground crew had trouble aligning the jet bridge with the new aircraft, which caused a delay and embarrassment for AA, considering DFW is their home airport.

The single seats along the windows offer a very private flying experience. The seat electronics are overly complicated, with a small tablet-like touch screen for selecting from a vast array of seat positions. At one point my seat control simply became unresponsive and the flight attendant had to "reboot my seat". Who'd ever thought that sentence would exist?

The new lay flat business seats are very private with the window seats angled towards the windows and the centers angled towards each other you have a very secluded feel.
The seats are a very good quality and a pleasant dark brown fabric which makes for a comfortable seat. Going fully flat into the bed is easy but it does resemble a coffin somewhat with very narrow foot space and a wider bowl up towards the head and shoulders.
American gives the width as 21-26 inches and I found that unless I scooted all the way up towards the top of the head portion my shoulders touched both sides when lying on my back. I am not a big guy - 5'9" and 190 pounds so taller, broader people may need to put the aisle arm rest down so they are not bumping their shoulders. At least that is a good option.
Row 5 does only have one window as opposed to two and so does the back row , row 8.
The windows are huge and the electronic dimming is amazing - you can set it to a deep blue while cruising. A very quiet aircraft and noticeable better on your airways and nasal passages without drying you out.

The new Premium Economy cabin is a very small cabin with only three rows of seats with a bulk head of sorts behind separating from Main Cabin Extra. The seat width is a big improvement from the typical coach seats American offers and the additional legroom is more or less on par with what you find in domestic first class at 38 inch pitch. With a two, three, two layout the middle seat in the center is tough and needs a person on the aisle to get up and move out to let someone out. The seats have wider arm rests as well so you are not competing for the arm rest with the person next to you. 
Good amount of recline and having a foot rest does make this a very comfortable alternative to standard coach or even MCE. The window two seats are the best bet.
Even though close to galley the seat was very private and noise was minimal. There were 2 windows so the view outside was very nice. The TV screens are large and there are several
Only 1 window at 5A and 5H. Structural item occupies where other window should be. Wish someone wrote this seat review before me so I could have picked another seat. I fly to look out windows.

I have flown this A319 a couple of times. One of the few American planes that seem to maintain a decent time table and not get delayed. 14A was for the most part comfortable, there is not a left arm rest that is reachable. There were personal TVs on my plane, that worked great. The plane was very quite too. Seat had pretty good cushion, I would fly this over most regional jets and any of the 737s. Bathrooms are pretty decent size too.

When AA introduced the A319 a few years ago, with the monitors I the seats, they were truly awful--like being wedged in a coffin.  Monitors are no more, but the 30" inch pitch is very uncomfortable for someone 6-3 with arthritic knees.  Don't ask AA the take a row out, not in these days of nickeling and diming you for everything imaginable.  A321s are much better.

Truly terrible seat.  The bulkhead panel is straight from the floor to the ceiling - no bend in the panel for leg room.  But the panel separating the tiny first-class section to the premier-economy section has a bend to allow an extra foot of leg-room.  The 8D bulkhead seat is actually a better seat than the 1D.  I was upgraded to 1D and I sat in the seat and found even less leg room than in the back of the bus.  I gave up that seat and returned to my previously assigned seat, 10D.  It was a much better experience.  Maybe a tiny person would like 1D but anyone with regular-sized legs would be infuriated to have paid extra for this seat.
There is no room for your legs. My son's legs touched the seat in front. It is so tight you cannot reach down and access your bag under the seat in front of you. THis is a total safety hazard.

Worst seats in aplane
You do not have any space ..I am 5'3" and my knees were touching the seat in the front, 
in my way back i upgrade the seat to Extra cabin and I was confortable, but main cabin it is imposible to fly more than 1 hour !!!

So you want to have the most cramped uncomfortable ride anywhere? Then book on American Airlines and fly on this plane. You won't be disappointed. 

I booked this flight from Barbados to Charlotte.
I'm 5'8" and usually don't have a problem even in standard coach. I couldn't even open my laptop without they keyboard in my belly and straining my neck to see the screen because the person in front of me had their seat back (So Did I). 

The problem with AA is they are trying to make more money and expecting customers to live with their actions. Speak with your pocket book folks!!

I'm a Diamond on Delta, was thinking about doing a challenge on AA but after this flight home from Barbados  and the flight from home to Barbados on American Airlines I can honestly say I'll never fly American Airlines again, and If they are the only carrier to get where I need to go I'll be cancelling my trip.

7:30PM departure from MIA to SFO. Not lie flat/pod seats, just basic domestic first class seats. They do not have Bose/high quality headsets for the entertainment system, which is pretty weak considering the shift to bluetooth.

This was the most cramped seat I have ever been in by far. A total joke...I will NEVER fly in this airplane again. Packed in like sardines, forget picking anything up off the ground, forget putting anything other than a phone in the pouch on the back of the seat in front of you.  Try to put an IPAD in that pouch? Forget it! I repeat, this is by far thee worst seating I have ever encountered.
This is the worst seat i have ever had.  American Airlines, looks like i will switch back to SWA
Extremely short leg space. Almos you dont fit in. Only one bag storage bin.

I fly on this plane from Miami to Manaus, Brazil frequently.  There is really no comfort on this plane, anywhere!  If you can avoid it.  Otherwise, this first row of the First/Business Class cabin for me works better than the second row.  I put my roll-on case in front of me, so my feet and legs have a nice place to rest and they are not just hanging there for 5 hours.
I found the foot space was very adequate, and I am a large person.  The seat was wide enough for me and I was pretty comfortable.  I had to bring my own seatbelt extender as AA didn't have one.
FYI, for the A319 with seat back entertainment the A/V boxes take some valuable leg room.

Be aware that there are two versions of the A319: the ones ordered by AA before their merger with US Airways have IFE screens and an AC outlet between the Y seats. All AA A319s have identical layout and seats, but the planes ordered by US Airways before the merger lack IFE and AC power outlets.

I don't know how to tell which one you'll get prior to departure other than the AA-bought planes have swept-up winglets and the US ones have small bladed ones that extend above and below the wings.
There is no arm rest for the left arm, so its uncomfortable. But you do get massive leg room and two windows.

This was a flight from las vegas to philadelphia. The seat is listed as an exit row seat. Its actually just a normal isle seat but it feels better because the window seat has no seat in front of it. It just opens up the row a bit. The plane is that new version with a bathroom by the exit row. No tv

This first class seat is just fine. I would much rather bring my own device than stare at a tiny airline screen. BTW, my iPad case hangs perfectly in the upper magazine slot, yet, i can move it anywhere i desire.  There IS a power outlet - in the center console storage. Best power arrangement as can have plugged in device during takeoff/landing w/o cords blocking egress. An efficient layout

On A319 AA1709 on 2/8/2018 from phx to sjc
Under seat area is obstructed, and legroom is restricted

I was pleasantly surprised by the comfort of this seat. It was a little wider than a comparable seat on a 737, enough wider that it made a real difference in my comfort. I also had plenty of legroom. I will be seeking out this aircraft for future flights.
The windows were offset. I had to either lean forward or look back to see out a window.

1-F is very pleasant.  The small 1st class seems to have enough overhead space, even if full, as you board first, extra bags can go above the first rows of coach and someone will hand them to you.  Leg room just OK but I can nap just fine in this seat.

When AA introduced the A319 a few years ago I thought it was horrible and said so on this site. They have been reconfigured with the same comfortable seats found in the latest A321s and are lights years better.  I am 6-3, and even at 31" inch pitch they are satisfactory.  I sprung for MCE on this flight and it was the most comfortable coach ride I have had in years. There is ample foot room and the seat back is high enough that it does not hit me in the middle of my neck like the MD80s when trying to recline.  Seat engineers did a good job on these, thanks, AA.
I found this seat to have restricted legroom compared to row 2 because, it's a bulkhead seat, but it reclined unlike row 2 seats.  Overhead storage bin was usable for this row.
No IFE, no power outlets. The first class seat is very thin, not comfortable with very little recline.  I can only image how bad economy must be

This is an updated aircraft which has a IFE in every seatback - welcome surprise.  Even in premium economy leg space is somewhat limited, if you have a bag under the seat,  due to power unit for the IFE.  No bag and you can stretch reasonably well, I'm 5'10 Seat is comfy and decent for a 3hr flight

The left arm rest for 14A is actually on the emergency exit and slightly higher and more forward than the arm rest on the right. This is less than ideal and should be included in the comments for both 14A and 14 F.

I was pleasantly surprised  with the amount of leg room in my seat. Even with my (packed to the gills) back pack under the seat in front of me I had plenty of room for my legs. Loved that there was an outlet built into the seats in front of me. Flight crew was kind and courteous.
This seat seemed pretty tight for a 30" pitch.

On my flight (MIA-YYZ), although the tray tables in the emergency exit row (row 14) were indeed on the seat back as a previous commenter wrote, there was ALSO for some reason another set of tray tables in the arm rests, making them immovable.
The overhead bin was empty and accessible. The emergency equipment was in a side compartment over the coat closet. Decent seat.

IND-PHX There were no personal screens on this aircraft. There was a few movies/TV shows available to stream and stated as free but we could never get connected. Updated interior with leather seats, plane was clean and service good. Tight squeeze in row 24. We sat in MCE on our way back to Indy (row 9 flight 500)no screens again but much better seats. There appears to be a partition between each window on this aircraft so you kinda have two windows per row but they don't exactly align. All in all, good flights.
My flight had no screens at all in any class.  One had to stream movies, etc on phone, tablet or laptop.  Weird if one wasn't prepared with headphones.
Great seat; plenty of leg room and leather seat.
A metal box, about 2 inches thick, is attached to the bottom frame of the seat in front of this one.  It cuts down on leg room and under seat storage

The seats appear to have been recently reconfigured to give less leg room, smaller pitch and a very cramped economy cabin. The armrests are hard plastic. All upholstery has been removed. Uncomfortable!
With the new upgrade, the tray tables in the exit row are in the seat back in front of you and the arm rests are movable.

Great seat.  Must have been an older version because no IFE from BNA to LAX.  I'm 5'9 and 34" of pitch is fantastic.  Very comfy overall.  Crew was nice, nothing special.  I definitely would take this flight/seat again.
Cramped. Avoid row 13. Pitch very small.

Really bad seat of you are tall. The space on front of the seat is reduced due to what im assuming is part of the wiring of the entretainment system. Additionally the seat is small and the window is slightly forward.

The legroom in the bulkhead is more limited in the newly retrofitted planes. (Or are they new?) The wall at the bulkhead is straight from ceiling to floor--formerly it angled out slightly allowing more leg room. I love the bulkhead but this newly limited legroom may change my future seat selection.
Utility box consumes foot room
Utility box consumes foot room
Utility box consumes foot space
Utility box consumes foot space
Great leg room.  Almost no recline.

There is another version of the A319, which are the ex-US Airways that have been reconfigured with the same seating but no IFE. There were also only 2 power outlets. I believe most LAX-YYZ flights are flown with this non-IFE configuration. It had gogo-inflight though. Still highly uncomfortable and very limited pitch for a coast to coast flight.

Flew GCM-MIA. Seat pitch is miserable, and IFE box under the seat further reduces leg room. Seat itself was reasonably comfortable for a short hop. IFE is nice, but personally I'd prefer to lose it altogether in exchange for another couple inches of seat pitch so my knees wouldn't have to be in contact with the seat in front of me. If you are over six feet tall, I recommend avoiding this aircraft unless you are in first, MCE, or emergency exit row.

Standard domestic first class seat.  Fresh leather seat surfaces.  New 120V outlets at all seats.  Next door seat  mate told me of a recent fire back in economy related to one of these outlets.  Exceptional food!.  YES!!  Restaurant quality!!  Attentive and extremely friendly flight crew.  Will take this flight again.
The 'A and E' seats will not permit the Ciao brand underseat rolling bag to be stored underneath the seat in front due to a built in obstruction on the right rear leg.

I flew on this plane just last month and AA recommended 14D. This was a newly renovated ex-US A319 which has the same seat setup and features as the legacy AA A319, minus the seatback TV. It was an averave flight, we were delayed an hour due to bad weather. It was a good thing they recommended this seat cause it was very roomy, especially cause I usually book legroom upgrades when I fly. I'm guessing probably a full 6" more pitch since MCE seats in exit rows always have about 6" more seat pitch. Contrary to this seat map, the tray table in this row is not in the armrest but in the seat in front of you, which does not impede the seat width. The seat itself is the same B/E Pinnacle slimline seat that United is using on their newly renovated 737's. The flight itself was kinda bumpy, but still enjoyable from the extra legroom.

You should note that personal on demand ife is not available on all A-319's with 8F seats. I've been on legacy AA A-319's and they offer personal ife screens at every seat. The redone legacy US-Air A-319 with 8 first class seats that I was on had the same seat layout, power, wifi etc as the original AA planes but they don't offer personal ife screens in coach or first.

I was in a bulkhead row, labeled Main Cabin Extra.  Overall, a seat and plane to be avoided.  Using this plane for a five hour flight from YYZ to LAX is abusive.  My seat was thinly padded and uncomfortable with the first class curtain slapping against my legs throughout the flight.  I also observed others sitting extremely uncomfortably in coach with their 30" pitch.  Unless you can get rows 9 or 10 in coach, just avoid the plane.

Took this flight late August 2016. Plane is new and seats thinly padded, with mininal legroom. These seats are the most cramped and uncomfortable of any flight I've taken in many years.  If you must fly on this plane, spend the money for plus seating.  Otherwise, try another plane or airline.
Main cabin extra has noticeably more leg room than economy which starts in row 11.

I flew on an ex-US Airways A319 from LAX-MCI that had the interior upgraded to this layout.  New leather seats matching the American scheme, but no television in the seat backs.  The seats were the same slimline they are now using without the screens.  MCE is the only way I would get on one of these new Airbus, the other seats are ridiculously tight.
Comments are accurate, but no TVs ;-( on flights from/to PHL to MSP.

I am an Executive Platinum customer and typically fly 737s on the LGA-MIA route. This flight was a pleasant surprise. Beautiful new leather seats, each equipped with TVs like you'd see on a A321 or a long-haul 777. Seat had ample legroom. The safety card read "06/16 REVISION" so I would believe it if someone told me the plane is brand spanking new. Nice to see American stepping it up, however they need to accelerate their fleet refresh
I LOVED THIS SEAT. IF THERE WAS NOT AN ON-DEMAND TV, I WOULD BE BORED.
I loved my seat. My seat was 11A.

I believe this aircraft is really comfortable, It was a 2 hour flight, the legroom was ok, and the IFE did not bother me at all. Great entertainment options. I love American's newest product, congrats on the new products American!

Although I am a Platinum passenger on AA, I had never flown on the A319 before. On the short flight from MIA to ATL my window seat in row 9 was comfortable, similar to the same seat on the A321. You do lose storage space under the seats due to the IFE boxes, which is true in more of the new planes now days.
Be aware of limited storage width due to the electrical box.

I have flown on this aircraft four times with AA.  Twice is First Class and twice in Coach.  My general comment is to avoid this aircraft it you have any other options.  The seats in First Class should not be considered Business/First Class. They are very uncomfortable and there is not a lot of leg room.  The coach seats are are even worse. They are hard with little leg room.  I am 6'1" 240.   I could hardly walk after flying on this aircraft.  I would only recommend flying on this aircraft if the flight time is only an hour to an hour and a half.

I sat in 10F on a flight from PHX-MCI.  Despite this plane being nearly 15 years old, the interior and seat were in great condition.  The window lenses were a bit scratched up, but it didn't affect the ability to see clearly. 

This is a Main Cabin Extra seat, and therefore has significantly more leg room that the standard economy class seat.  I have uploaded pictures to show the leg room.  I am only 5'6", so leg room typically is not an issue, but I was able to upgrade to MCE for free, so I thought I would try it out.

The pitch on these seats. Is miserable.  You cannot really open the tray table and the video monitor is about 10 inches away from your face.  If there was ever a "mainline" plane to avoid, it is this configuration of American's A319

Wow.  I don't believe I have ever flown a jet this uncomfortable.  I am 6'1 and 190 and while the width is OK, the pitch of this seat and the lack of recline are killing me as I am on the plane presently.  I always thought all coach seats were identical so I guess I learned my lesson.  It goes without saying that this is going to be my last trip on this type of equipment.

What terrible news this is the "flagship" or American (if indeed it is).  First Class is OK, but only 8 seats, meaning even Exec Platinums rarely get upgrades.  Coach seats are awful.  Recline is the least I've ever experienced, except for Spirit, which has no recline.   The seats recline about 1 inch.  The backs are thin and hard and shaped wrong...no support.   And there's no IFE!  Only positive comment is Exit Row seats have great legroom.   But that doesn't make the seat comfortable.  Don't, repeat don't book on this plane if you can avoid it...unless you can get into First Class (which BTW is really like Premium Economy).

Absolutely the worst aircraft to fly for comfort in economy. I actually thought I was in Main Cabin Extra.  My error.  Nice leather seats with no leg room. From front edge of seat to back of the seat in front of me was less than 12 inches, I measured 10.5 inches.  I am 5'5 and I really felt bad for the men in my row.  Only 8 first class seats if you try to upgrade.  I shall not fly the Airbus 319 again if I can help it.
Seat is full-width but is missing right-side armrest, which is uncomfortable. (14A is also missing left armrest.)

All  negative comments are correct. I had 4 segments on this "new" airbus 319, 1 in "first" and 3 in coach. First is comparable to premium economy in better INT carriers like Cathay, but legroom is fair. However in coach/cattle class the seats are the worst I've ever experienced (even worse then Spirit airlines if that is possible). I am 6'1 185lbs and I sat Aisle, middle and window and all were terrible - window being the worst, most narrow and the electical box in front. Even on a 1.5 hour flight my back and knees were sore and many others in the flight were complaining of the same problems. This is 3 steps backward for passenger comfort, whoever green-lit this  design should lose their employment at AA. If the fares were 75% discounted to similar routes, I could understand but they aren't.

BOS-DCA. As long-time Plat, I reserved 11d thinking it was MCE.  Turns out there are only 3 rows of MCE (8, 19, 10), and the 1st one is bulkhead (= less leg room). I was one of the few who actually liked USAir; now I really miss it.
Flew this DSM to PHX. Not the regular equipment for this segment. No entertainment system - space where the screen goes is extra storage. AC power between each seat. Plenty of leg room in MCE.

I read the scathing comments on this plane before my ATL -> LAX trip and was seriously dreading it based on the negativity.  However, I was pleasantly surprised - the IFE boxes below the seats were not as intrusive as I was expecting based on the reviews, so I had plenty of legroom (note: I'm 5'5").  And my son was able to play on his laptop without feeling like it was in his face sitting on the tray table.  Our row did not recline due to being directly in front of the exit row, but it wasn't bad.  All in all, a much better flight than I anticipated.  Crew were extremely friendly to boot.

Forget about limited recline, the seat DOES NOT recline. Between the lack of storage under the seat for row 1 and the lack of recline in row 2, this aircraft should not advertise this a a first class cabin

I have traveled on this aircraft from MIA to IAH. No problem with the legroom because i'm short (1,60 m), would liked more recline. It haves some free entertaiment options or premium for purchase. New seat, confortable. In fact, a good experience.
The IFE screen is nearly in your face when the row ahead is reclined. This is an extremely uncomfortable aircraft unless in F or MCE.

14A is an very good exit row/Main Cabin Extra seat with a seat pitch in excess of the other MCE seats and more legroom than 1st class on the LUS A319 layout (which I flew on my outbound leg). This new layout thankfully has power outlets (only 2 per row though).  I couldn't find the USB outlets though.  The leg room is a little cramped in 14A (and all economy window seats I believe) due to presence of a small electrical box which makes storing a larger bad underneath the seat problematic.  If you want maximum under seat storage space and lots of leg room, take the exit row middle seat.  Overall seat comfort of these new "slim line" seats isn't great for a long distance trip (mine was 4.5 hrs) but should be fine for less and 2 hours.

Very comfortable bulkhead seat.  Unfortunately there are no "feet cut outs" so your toes are against the wall.  On my flight my entertainment did not work but the person next to me had no problem.  At least the maps worked.

This is the first row of economy. Our party of 6 reserved it. I find that it's in the best location of the cabin. There is lots of space, however the legroom is just a tiny bit less than in the other MCE seats behind this row. I'm 5 foot 7 inches, I could stretch my feet out with no problem and I could get out without the other people in this row gettin gout of their seats. Of course absoutely fantastic service on American and they did a great job with the IFE and power!
I was just on a version of this plane with this seat layout (8 first class seats) and no AVOD. It looks like that is how they are refreshing the ex-US Airways A319s

I'm only 5'6" tall and felt really crammed in this seat. There is very little space between your seat and the one in front of you. The electronics boxes also cut down on the space underneath the seat in front of you. I really had to do a contortion act to get my things into and out of this space.

I've flown on A319s previously with other airlines and not had these issues. This is pretty ridiculous. I can't recommend this plane to anyone. Avoid it if you can.
Wow...avoid if at all possible.  This aircraft is a great example of the current state of flying in the US.  Cram as much on the plane as possible regardless of passenger comfort. Just horrible.

The seat width of 17.7" is like a straitjacket, even with the extra legroom in MCE.  It's intolerable for a 4 hr. plus international flight (DFW to Panama City).  Also, the seats and backs are thinly padded, less comfortable than the 1 hour Embraer commuter flight on Copa from PTY to David City.  I won't fly on an A319 again.
Seats 25A and 25B both have boxes under the seat in front of them reducing legroom.

I am 6'4'' and was not able to sit in this seat without pain for the duration of the flight. Absolutely no leg room. Additionally, electronic charger outlet is placed exactly where your right knee hits the front seat. Worst airplane I have been on - avoid at all cost!

This seat along with 22f should be marked as less desirable.  It has a box in the leg room area that consumes about 6 inches of the available horizontal space.  I think this is for the ife. I wish i had known this when selecting seats.
The IFE box really kills what little under seat storage there is. That and the seat pitch is nothing (even as a "preferred") that im glad it was only a 45 min flight. Any longer.... oh boy.

Dreadful - worst flight in a decade. Putting video boxes under seats was stupid 15 years ago. These days it's insanity.

Nowhere to put my legs, nowhere to put my bag, seat in from straight in my face. Will avoid at all costs in the future.

Exit Row 14D ONLY seat (14C/D) worth sitting on in this tin box. Unlimited legroom...much better than restrictive first class bulkhead. As for the plane...announcements were unintelligble with static (FAA violation?). Thank you to AA attendants to make this flight tolerable despite the equipment.

I do not agree this is a standard MCE seat.  MCE feels noticeably smaller on this aircraft.  Even before the person in front of me reclined, I could not open my laptop on the tray table.  I was ironically reminded of the AA promotional video wherein the space in front of the woman expands and she opens her laptop.  No way she'd open that laptop on this plane.

The comment about there being only 8 seats in First is also true.  I am Exec Plat and was fourth on the upgrade list (obviously didn't get it).

I will avoid this aircraft in future.

That "new plane smell" AA has been talking about is great, but that "new plane butt" is painful.  Don't fly this airplane if you have a choice.  If you don't, bring a pillow to sit on - you're gonna need it.

All seats should be marked red. These "new" for American, European style vinyl seats-look-likes are like tight filled potato bags to sit on. At least BAQ-MIA and v.v. is international leg and have pillow(s)one can shove them under the butt.
Have 30 yrs, 4.5 million miles, life Platnm at AA and these are absolutely the WORST seats I ever landed on AA.
This for 2.5 hr flight. Anything for 3 hrs or more, NO way, No matter what.
Worst aircraft in the flight, which I try to avoid but getting more difficult.  As an Exec Plat I've never gotten an upgrade and even the Main Cabin Extra seats make me miss the departing MD-80's.

First off, i flew this plane from Bogota to Dallas on a red eye. You have to PAY for movies, even though it was a 6 HOUR international flight.

Second, seatguru please change every seat in economy to red, unless you are 5 feet tall. At 6 foot, my knees hit the seat in front of me, and forget about sleeping.

I have been Plat for 5 years and this is by far the worst plane I have ever been on.

These "first class" seats in the last row of  First/business don't recline all the way. There is a hard Bulkhead that prevents full recline.  Also seat pitch seems pretty close for a First class.  Not a great setup.

Cramped, cramped, cramped (I'm 5' 9") - most uncomfortable plane in the sky - even Spirit comes out ahead of this #aafailure. The IFE box takes away the ability to store your 'personal item'. I wear reading glasses and couldn't read anything on the IFE - too far away without glasses and had to lean way forward to try to read with them. What idiots designed this cabin? AVOID AT ALL COSTS
Switch flights or pay for premium seating in the Main "Extra" seats. Economy seating is ridiculously confining. Find a CRJ to fly on.

I am a Gold/Platinum status flyer since 2004.  This was the most cramped leg room I have ever experienced on a flight.  Even the small CRJs have more leg room.  My knees were crammed into the seat in front of me and I'm only 5'7". The US Airways configuration for this plane is roomy compared to this crazy configuration.  I suggest avoiding this plane all together. I am not impressed with this plane. I would happily give up the entertainment to have pain-free knees!!

At 6'6" we paid to ensure we could get exit row seating (AA Gold get half off) and I can't imagine flying in the other sardinelike seating.

A tall person will find it impossible to sleep or even sit fully back in the short-backed seats. The headrest has limited adjustments but even on this very new plane they would already fall right back down the moment you no longer apply pressure.   Leg room in the exit row is plentiful, fortunately.

This plane only has two restrooms for coach, all the way in the back, to service 100 pax.  The lav in first class, which services all of eight people, is guarded to keep the riff-raff out.   There's very little room back there to stand and the crew don't like you invading their space, and do their darndest to stay back there as long as possible.

The entertainment system is basically useless because you have to pay for almost anything offered (and bring your earbuds or pay another $5 for those).  Onboard wifi is also ridiculously expensive at over $20 for the flight.  Guy next to me used his cell phone for his wireless, which I think is still against the rules.

There is no doubt the design of this interior is more about the Benjamins than the customer.   I miss my old MD-80s.   With only 8 seats in first, you can forget about scoring an upgrade unless you're Exec Plat, too (not that it was easy otherwise before).

I agree with others' comments about the seating discomfort on this plane, and would add that the "entertainment unit" storage subtracts foot room on all seats, including aisle seats.  Even the "main cabin extra" seat that I had (which did not recline, due to mechanical error).  Compared to the soon to be departed MD80s, these seats are narrower, and have 1" less legroom in main economy and 1"-3" less legroom in main cabin extra.  Too bad these are the "new standard."

My wife and I flew from Miami to Belize on 7/14 and were sitting in seats 2D & 2F. For what are essentially domestic first class seats we found these seats to be very comfortable and the whole flight experience to be very good. The IFE is very similar to the one found in the new 777-300ER, which is a great system. We had friends in 9D & 9F and they also had no complaints about the seats in MCE. I would be happy to fly this plane on pretty much any domestic route.

This plane makes me miss the MD-80!!!!  By far the worse plane I have ever been on except perhaps the old ATR prop plane.  I have been Plat/Exec Plat for over a decade and have flown on every plane AA has put in the air over that period.  AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

The interior is very beutiful. The seats have good leg room. The seats are a little stiff, but overall you have godd IFE (in-flight intertainment) and is a very quiet aircraft versus a 757. I would give American a 7/10.

Every seat on this plane should be yellow or red.  The 'entertainment system' in the backs of the seats place the seat back about 8" from your face, and God forbid the person in front of you reclines. I will walk before I fly on one of these again.

I couldn't believe how uncomfortable these seats are. We live in Cayman and fly to Miami via AA 5+ times per year but this was our first flight on this new plane and we will do everything we can to avoid a repeat in the future. I was in a window and there wasn't enough room to store my purse with the box there, nonetheless my legs. I'm 5'9" and my husband, who was in the middle, is 6', and we were both miserable on this flight. We both have had back surgery, and sitting feeling like you're pitched forward with zero lumbar or cushion support is awful even for a short flight. I cannot imagine flying long haul on it, but I would pay double for another airline with better seats. It's sad because we generally like AA even though most don't, but this plane (even for a 1 hour flight) is just ridiculously bad. Luckily no one reclined into me, but if they had I probably would have come close to a panic attack because it was already way too tight in the seat. Skip this plane if at all possible, especially if your flight is lengthy.

If you are taller than 5' 10" or have an inseam longer than 30 this is without a doubt the most uncomfortable seat you could find. The headrest would not stay up, recline was limited and the window seat is noticeably several inches thinner than the middle or aisle seats.  Add the entertainment box crammed under there and you have discomfort awaiting.  Had to wiggle in sideways or press my knees against the seat in front of me (until they reclined...

Flew on this plane from Dallas to Lubbock yesterday 3/30/15.  Sat in 2F not a very comfortable seat.  I would not fly on this type of plane on a flight longer than 1 hour.  Seat was miserable seat cushion paper thin.  Service was good and entertainment screen was fine with many options. MD-80's much more comfortable.

On winter 2013-2014, I flew BOG-DFW-ORD and return... I thought this AA's improvement was going to satisfy me, but no! This plane was extremely uncomfortable for a 5+ hr overnight flight. Seats are narrow, the plane feels really cramped, I couldn't even stretch my legs (I'm 6 ft tall)... Besides that, the returning flight was delayed for more than 15 hours at DFW, and flying this plane after waiting that time was like a nightmare (For this leg, I decided to pay more to travel on Main Cabin Extra, and at least I could stretch my legs)... I found out MD 80's domestic-used planes were more comfortable than A319 ones... Despite the fact that DFW airport is really easy to navigate for international passengers, I'll try to avoid this plane  overall the next time I travel to the US

Suggestion: If you can't avoid flying this plane, don't choose a window seat! Instead of that, choose an aisle one, even if you have to pay more for that...
All Rows have entertainment boxes beneath the seats. Armrests are movable although the lever is small and a little hard to operate.

As another has mentioned, the seat is itself is fine. It is no different than the ones Delta and United are using to reconfigure in there economy section. It is the placement of the entertainment box in the window and middle seats that forces you to angle your feet in order to maximize your legroom. My advice is to pick the aisle seat (pay extra if you have to). I am 5'10 and no, my knees were not touching the seat in front of me.

Without a doubt the tightest, smallest, least comfortable seat since the days of Airtran. This is progress? That this is AA's new flagship is a joke.  Who was in charge of stategy, the Munchkins?

Two flights on UA instead in nonstop on this turkey is a no brainer.  Its hard to imagine a corporate management so clueless....of course they go First
Good legroom, universal power port, quiet flight, comfy seat, my TV worked, the seats next to mine's TVs didn't work, jerky flight attendants.
The new chair are not the issue, is the HUGE box on the floor that is not aligned with the chair.  This makes it rub into your leg the entire flight.  it's actually worst on the window seat.

Absolutely the most uncomfortable plane ride in years. Even worse than the European budget airlines. Claustrophobic and I was on the aisle! I could not get my small water in the seat pocket, had to fold my tray table down to get the safety instructions out of the plastic back of the seat in from of me! Impossible to juggle a sandwhich and a drink at the same time. Elite moving back to SWA.

All baffiling has been beaten out of this ancient flying nightmare. It leaves ORD to EWR. Its freezing onboard and "too old to keep steady heat," low 60s, mid 50s overnight... that cute blanket ... grab that and another or your jacket, and forget about sleeping...

The interference in leg room from the entertainment power units must not be taken lightly.. For anyone over about 5'5" this is a big discomfort.. I will avoid in future. Sure would like to know how this type of connfiguration gets this far down the road.. Not well researched/ tested

Again, all the comments about this plane are accurate.  I was in a standard coach seat and was watching the video screen.  When the passenger in front of me reclined, the screen was so close I could not focus on it.  I ended up just turning it off.  And of course there was no where near enough room for a laptop. I'm Exec Plat with AA so obviously I'm on many of their planes.  This was the most miserable by far.  Now when I fly DFW YYZ, I connect in ORD or LGA just to avoid this plane. My most recent ticket was about $100 more than the non-stop but I willingly paid it.

LAX-DFW-BOG return and worst flights ever. Pitch is stupidly small.  I'm 6 3 and even before I tried to recline I could only just get my shins under the bottom of the seat in front.  Recline is a couple of inches and the seat tilts up and there goes any thought of legs extending. To avoid jamming my knees against the reclined seat in front I end up sitting sideways. For 5 hours.
I aould go out of my way to avoid the A319 as flown by AA.

AA got this plane layout totally wrong - I purchased a First Class seat and while the FE screen was nice the seat pitch is less than the old MD80. I flew another flight in coach and thankfully only a 2 hour flight - horrible seats. It is a sad fact that I prefer the old MD80 to this aircraft - shame on AA for putting out this as an "improvement". The MD80 has a first class to economy ratio of @1-8 giving a FF a chance of an upgrade. The "new and improved" A319 has a ratio of @1-14 nearly twice as bad. I will avoid this aircraft at all costs

These seats are miserable as the entertainment boxes take up so much of the leg room as to be nonexistent if you put your purse below. The box for the window seats take up so much room that you sit at an angle and there is no room for even a medium sized purse. Shame on you American Airlines for thinking this is great customer service. I would like all of the AA executives to fly in these miserable seats.
I agree. Avoid this airplane. Seats to close and uncomfortable. My back hurt throughout the flight.

I was honestly excited to hear AA was adding the Airbus to their fleet.  That excitement was short lived.  This is honestly the WORST airplane I've ever been on.   The seating configuration is terrible, the seats are uncomfortable, there is no space in the seat back pocket to even place a bottle of water.  It's sad that I prefer the old MD80 to the 319.  AVOID this aircraft at all costs.
Leg room is very restricted. Seat cushion is inexistent and the seat barely reclines. Lots of traffic to bathrooms during red-eye flight make nearly impossible to sleep.

All first class seats should be marked at least yellow.  The recline is terrible in both rows.  In row 1 the bulkhead is so close that I could come nowhere close to stretching out my legs (average height male).  If you are a corporate travel professional, demand AA grant lower rates for these seats they are not "first class" by any measure.

This was a First Class seat.  In this new Premium Cabin environment, the seat backs are lower and narrower, so every word the passengers in front of or behind you say interrupts your thoughts, concentration and/or conversation with the person sitting next to you.  A case in point is that the passenger in front of me has shaken the ice in his scotch THE ENTIRE FLIGHT and I've HEARD it THE ENTIRE FLIGHT.  The tray tables are too small and sit too close to your body.  The seat in front of you lays back into your space.  My laptop could not be opened fully when the seat in front of me was reclined.  There's only a thin wall between First and Coach which is not even sealed off at the walls, so the light from the window behind in Coach comes through, interfering with the video screen in the seat back in front of me and there is little physical barricade to the noise from the first row in Coach (considerable on my particular flight).  The lack of storage for the in-flight blanket meant it either ended up on the floor or under my arm.  As much as AA needed to upgrade it's equipment and replace its S80s, this was a poorly thought out aircraft from the passenger's perspective.  It's nice to have seat back enterrainment, but other than that and the "new car smell", this is a very uncomfortable and cramped aircraft and whenever possible I avoid flyingit.

Just flew back from Bogata,CO..business class..all nighter.this seat is terrible..doesnt relcone at all..the seats on this plane "slide" forward..impossible to sleep. The whole First Class cabin only has 8 seats..very small and cramped. Fine for a daytime short haul...HORRIBLE for a LONG haul...

Every single one of the reviews here is dead on accurate.  American must have consulted Ryanair before they configured the seats here.  30" seat pitch is ridiculous.   The curvature of the seats does absolutely allow for more cattle to be placed in steerage but I can't hardly even see my laptop as I write this review based on how I have to have it cranked.  The plane itself is new and quiet but that's about it.  Avoid this at all costs unless you're in 1st or an exit row.  I'd fly a 15 year old ERJ-135 before I'd fly this again.

I had the misfortune of flying an A319 from Dallas to Huntsville.  The seats have been reconfigured to thin the lower portion of the seat in front, to allow your seat to be jammed even closer.  The seat pocket and tray table have been moved up, consuming the volume in front of your face.  You are so close to the seat in front of you that you cannot hold or read a magazine.  The lower corner of the seat in front is so low that you cannot put your feet under the seat without bruising your chins, if there were even space to do it, as that volume has been used up by the entertainment equipment, of which 2 of the 3 on my row did not work.  (The privacy screen prevents knowing how many others did not work)  The tray table is double hinged because there is not sufficient room for it.  The plane is so claustrophobic that people are having panic attacks in it.  Watch the news.  I am 6 ft, 190 lbs.  I travel for business and had to buy a first class upgrade, out of pocket, for the return flight.  Never again will I fly an AA A319. I complained to AA and was told this is their Flagship!!!

Excellent business class product at a reasonable price.  Seat is comfortable and lots of room too.  I'm a larger guy so the only complaint is that the fold out table doesn't push out far enough to accommodate me.

These seats have virtually no storage in the seat back pocket and if you stow anything under the seat you will have no legroom.  The seats are so close together that it is very difficult to access anything under the seats if the seat ahead is reclined.

Flew in MCE from DFW to Bogota.  As someone who usually sits in front, but this time sat in back as I had my kids, I found the seat extremely comfortable, with decent leg room and great entertainment.  I'd take this over a S80 any day of the week.  Kids loved the shows and games and we had excellent service for a long (5 1/2 hour) flight.  Overall - very satisfied with the new A319 -- great aircraft!

I try to avoid the 319 as much as I can although as they retire the MD80's it will become more difficult to do so. I am average height - 5'9" and sitting in 14A was the most uncomfortable I have been in years. The window exit actually curves into your space slightly as well as having the curvature of the cabin reduce your shoulder and head room. I was sat next to a big guy who was miserable and who could not help but have his shoulders against mine, consequently I spent 2.5 hours crammed up against the wall.
I am an Executive Platinum and I will go out of my way to avoid this equipment.

I've flown a lot of Airbus equipment before, including the A319, and have found them comfortable enough.  But that was before my first trip on an AA configured A319.  The arm rests cannot be raised on any economy aisle/window seats in the plane.  Most airlines give some flexibility to relieve crowding by raising an arm rest.  But not this monstrosity.  Ditto to the comments of other guru's regarding narrowness and tightness of seats in the back.

Exit row seats are reasonably comfortable compared to other economy seats. Actually had room to cross my legs. Not as claustrophobic as the rest of economy. On a later flight I sat in 14C and noticed it was not as wide as 14A since exit row seats have non-moveable armrests. I normally like the aisle but will choose exit row window seats on this aircraft. I did like having both AC & USB power at every seat.

I was very disappointed in overall cabin configuration for the following reasons:  

1. In typical Airbus fashion the entertainment system occupies significant space under seats A, B, E, and F. This prevented underseat storage of my small computer bag which fits fine elsewhere, even Regional Jets. This necessitated storage in the overhead bin.  Multiply this by the number of pax in similar situation and it places great and unnecessary demands on overhead storage.  Furthermore, the configuration resulted in very tight and uncomfortable legroom with my right leg frequently pressing uncomfortably against the metal box under the seat.

2.  The pitch between seats was too small, I'm 6ft 1in and my knees were pressing against the seat most of the flight.  My face was barely 15 inches from the seat in front of me.  Also, seat cushions are too thin.  

3.  The entertainment system didn't work (reported to cabin staff) - why even have it on aircraft operating short domestic flights?  Remove it and retrieve under seat space, reduce weight and maintenance costs.

4. Only 1 overwing emergency exit? While it may pass FAA evacuation tests, I question whether it will be effective with panicky pax unfamiliar with emergency procedures as well as cluttered and tight seat rows.

Probably the worst seat on the worst airline I've ever ridden.  Absolutely no room.  Tray table the size of a business letter envelope.  No way to use a notebook or read or do anything else but watch video.
Zero room for feet or any small item under seat. (Not that you could reach down there anyway).  Video screen and magazine rack directly in front of your face.  I'll find another carrier or drive before getting on another of those disgusting birds.

The Airbus 319A is an absolute joke.  I am 6'2", 175 lbs. and I have never been more uncomfortable on an airplane in my life. I could not put my legs under the seat in front of me. In fact, it wasn't even close. The seats are so close together that when I tried to extend my legs, my shins hit the bottom of the seat in front of me.  Not that there was any room for them under the seat anyway given the "entertainment box."  What kind of an idiot designs a plane with a box located under the seat?  When the person in front of me reclined, I nearly came unglued. I literally felt like seat back was 8" from my face.  As I was sitting there, I kept asking myself whether anyone from AA actually sat in the coach section before they decided to purchase/lease the 319A. The sad thing is I know they did--and that they just don't care at all about the comfort of their customers.  I will do my best to never fly AA again.  EVER.

Extremely limited recline, tray table is very tight - does not push away from the body as it does on the MD80, though the bulkhead is not particularly close or restrictive (and I'm 6'3). Personal video screen is nice but controls not intuitive and wired remote that nests in the armrest gets tangled.

Video equipment under seats reduces the under-seat space significantly in terms of width.  In the window seat I was in, it was further reduced by the curvature of the aircraft cutting in.  30" of seat pitch is awfully tight, even by the latest standards.  The plane is wonderful and new, but they've got you crammed in so tight, it would be hard for me to imagine being crammed in here for longer than the 1 hour flight I was on.

The tray tables are very shallow, impossible to put a laptop on them of any decent size.  I'm 5'5" tall and I felt cramped.  Other airlines A319's are far easier to handle.

Explat flyer lucky enough to get a seat upfront but the seat pitch was laughable and only 4 seats. Come on AA you know this config is your bread and butter business flight yet only two rows for your best customers.  Shame shame.  But thank goodness we have choices.  theres no reason to fly AA if your loyalty is based on getting upgraded with only two rows your chances just went from remote  to very very remote.

This was the worst seating experience since flying AirTran years ago. I literally could not fully open my laptop with the seat in front "upright". Even the seat back pocket is so small, you can't fit a hardback book in it. First class has fewer seats, so good luck getting an upgrade if you aren't Exec Plat. Avoid this equipment at all costs.

Without question, the most uncomfortable coach seat I've ever been in. I couldn't even get my feet under the seat in front of me for a little relief, because the bottom of the seat was so close it hit me in the middle of my shin.

The shape of the seat allows them to cram the rows tighter together while technically leaving the pitch unchanged, but the reality is that it's the tightest coach I've ever been in. Even United's standard economy isn't this bad.

Unless you're in first class, avoid this aircraft at all costs.  The MD-80 I came in on was much, much more comfortable.

Unbelievably cramped.  I'm just over 6 feet tall and it is the most uncomfortable seat I've been in - and that's before the seat in front of you is reclined.  If that happens the amount of space you are left with is comical.  The video screen doesn't tilt to accommodate the fact that, with the seat in front reclined, the line of sight is almost below your chin.  When designing the seating layout of this craft there was only one priority: revenue generation.

Tray tables are more narrow on this new plane than older planes. Can't fit a laptop and a drink. Seat pockets won't hold a drink either. Row 11 is first row that is NOT Main Cabin Extra, and it has very little room for a laptop between new seat back screens and less legroom.
I have never been more cramped on an airplane than on this one.  Extremely uncomfortable.  I will avoid this plane at all cost in the future- even never flying American again.

I’ve flown on boeing all my life until this month. Found the airbus a bit more comfortable and the engines were quite impressive. Always prefer window but aisle seat was ok. Beware of try service as I was bumped slight a couple of times.
If you'd like a view of the flaps and trailing edge of the wing, pick row 19.

A320 06/18 Revision per Safety Information Card had Power at this row of seats (one USB and one multi-plug type just below knee level for each seat, no shared plug), which were Regular Economy.  Still no TV.
I felt this seat was extremely roomy. I had great leg room and am 5'9" tall and above average in weight. Did not feel cramped in the least bit. Put a bag under seat in front of me as well.
These are regular economy seats but these A320s seem more to have more leg room than the 737s.
Not impressed with legroom for this first class seat from PHL-FLL. (Photo with orange bag shows my leg leaning toward left)
In the exit rows the tray table is installed in a fixed armrest, therefore, seat width is slightly reduced.

Seat was fine, minimal leg room but not cramped on aisle seat.  Cramped with passengers beside me.  No internet service or entertainment on this flight - AA should have this for a 3 hour flight.  AA should not have 60 min connection times for international flights, and have them on the other side of the airport.  Luggage took way too long, and had to abandon it and run to make my connection.  In Toronto, AA found my bag next day, kudos.

ok so i was flying from phl-pbi ok so the seat i sat in was comfortable i just had something to say i did not like my experience ok so american said ok flights on time we got on the aircraft oh there is a storm 15-30 min then a another 15-30 min then a second storm we were on the plane at the gate for 2 hours i hate that then due medical reasons they could could not brink the cart down how lovely is that they only served warm water and the flight was longer then usual not counting that awful delay hope to never fly you again also on the flight obi-phl it was just delayed 3 hours no big deal come on american step up your game cause I'm pretty sure on pho-pbi they knew about the storm just that want to be mean they're were also crying babies so loud it so annoying waiting for 2 hours on a plane with crying babies is terrible p.s. never flying american again

Standard Domestic first Class.  No meal on 1h45m OAK-PHX, just snacks/drinks - all I need at 6AM.  Service totally depends on attitude of the attendants.  Today: friendly and helpful (on my connection:  Gina grumpy-pants)  A decent deal for the price.
Wall rib is right in my shoulder.
I had no problems with this seat.  Flew at night so really couldn't see out much.  Very comfortable. leg room was fine.  Flight was only just an hour and half flight.

Seats are much more comfortable than AA 737 seats. Would highly recommend seeking the a320 over the 737. 

Overall not bad but not great. It gets the job done.

I flew round trip from DCA-MCO on late afternoon/evening flights and found this seat to be pretty good, but there were a couple things that may have bothered other people, that weren't an issue for me. First, since I'm only 5'3, legroom isn't an issue for me, but even when I stretched out my legs I didn't feel cramped. Second and probably the main reason was that it was only a 2 hour flight. Since the flight was so short, neither me nor the person in front of me reclined. I didn't mind a lack of a  USB or AC power outlet, though I probably would've on a longer flight. Service was typical for a 2 hour flight, as the FA's came around once for pretzels and drinks. The seat was wide enough and I would highly recommend this row for window lovers, as this row sports two windows. Overall, this was a good seat for a short flight, but I might consider upgrading to main cabin extra on a 4-5 hour flight.
The seats must have gotten a new upholstering. They are pretty comfortable.

Ridiculously small & little legroom for first class.  No IFE or Power ports - and it was a newer plane - why does AA fly this junk?  Offered streaming to personal devices in Y, but no one's feed worked, so little bandwidth.
None of the seats on this aircraft, first class or coach, has power outlets. Beware if you're expecting to be able to recharge your device once on board.

The seat was very cramped and I would have prefered to fly in 11D. Or the four aisle seats in the second exit row. However, the view from the seat was amazing. If you like taking pictures 14A has a great view of the wing and air.

Flew economy Philadelphia-Las Vegas on a newly refurbished A320. What a difference ia refurb makes! The seats felt and smelled fresh in the smart AA dark grey upholstery. I'm 6'2 and there was plenty of room for my long legs when sitting. I had a real treat though as the flight was barely half full so all 3 seats to myself meaning I could lie across them and sleep for over 4 hours! There's still no IFE even after the refurb but wifi is available to buy on board. Complementary non-alcoholic drinks were offered and snacks available for purchase.
Comfortable plane with good legroom. Only complaint is no IFE but other than that, good flight.

While this A320 still has the original US Airways interior, it is more than satisfactory for a short 2 hour flight. Flying from PHX-SMF, I could have chosen to fly Southwest, but not only was the American fare actually cheaper at the time, but the seats are much more desirable. No IFE or power outlets, but these amenities really aren't all that important on shorter flights. The wi-fi at least tells me the time to destination, which is really all I need.

Seats behind the rere emergency seats on American Airlines A330-200 should be flagged as the emergency seats are used as a crew rest area with the seat backs pushed back for duration of flight and area curtained off making it a bit claustrophobic in seats 24A, 24B, 24G and 24H.

We did not find the seat headrests to be comfortable at all.
They were at a very uncomfortable height and angle for both my husband (6'2") and I myself at 5'5". In addition there wasn't any inflight entertainment available...no screens for movies! Very unusual on a 6 hour flight!

Seat Legroom:  I am only 5'6", so leg room was not an issue.  I had no problem getting my personal carry-on item between my seat cushion and the seat back of the seat in front of me, and under the seat in front of me.    
Seat Recline:  I did not use the reclining feature, the flight was too short for that to matter.  
Seat Width:  I found the seat width to be comfortable for my slightly above average frame.  
This seat had one window, positioned slightly forward of my shoulder when I sat back in the seat.  The fuselage panels did not obstruct movement or make leaning against the wall uncomfortable.

Flew this red-eye flight from SEA-CLT; flighttime of 4h15. As with other ex-US Airways aircraft, the seats are a bit older but still comfortable and pitch is adequate. There isn't much recline on a standard economy seat- don't expect to get much sleep, but comfort and space-wise, it is fine for a multi-hour trip. No IFE or power, but apparently streaming vidéo is possible via the Wifi for a fee.

Flew from CLT->SJO. This plane was an A320neo, and so it was VERY new, delivered maybe March 2016. Snack and drink cart came by twice on this four-hour flight, which is acceptable, but everything good is gone when they get to the back of the plane. SeatGuru says that they had 31 inch seat pitch but it seemed like a lot less. Good thing I am short so I had an alright flight. 22F had one full window and another one between 22F and 21F. Overall, well done American!
Flew this plane on US Airways, very comfortable unlike Delta.

7F is a standard economy seat. Nothing special. If you want WIFI, buy the day pass for $16 BEFORE you go up in the air. Once airborne, AA wanted $40 for a one day pass on a flight from PHX to DCA. Always cheaper on the ground.
Nice legroom and good recline

Flew DEN to PHX.  This seat was tolerable for the 1.5 hour flight only due to the fact that the person in front of me did not recline her seat.  Very cramped feeling due to the tight seat pitch.  This aircraft was still in U.S. Air livery.  We can hope that American will add MCE seating.

This seat is really tight. I had a tall man next to me and the 5 hour flight was really hard. Very uncomfortable and very crammed seat. I am only 5'8" male at 180 lbs and I was REALLY crammed on this seat
Worst Airline ever!  Row 4 first class seats do not recline.  They are fixed at upright.   What arent they thinking.  Irritating 1/4 of their first class cabin even before takeoff.

They should call this seat the "thrombosis" seat. They call this an exit row - it is NOT except for the window seat, which has no seat in front of it. The other two are unbearable - especially "B". I am an average size woman. The person in front of me leaned back and I could not fully open my tray table - it is hinged- and I had to hold my book up to my face to read. This was the most miserable 3 hours of my life.
There was a metal box under the seat in front which reduced storage space. (I think most economy seats have this problem.
This seat or region of the plane gets very hot. The crew was aware and said this whole area of the aircraft gets less circulation than the rest
Overhead bin over starboard row 11 exit has limited storage due to equipment. Can fit coat or small bag, no luggage.  Overhead bin over starboard row 13 houses life raft and does not allow stowage.
Main cabin  extra seat lots of leg room even with seat infront of me reclined.  Decent space for feet despite IFE box. Overall very comfortable.

This airplane seat has 2 inches more pitch than layout 2 and it made a difference.  I was able to cross my legs with no problem.  It was only a snack flight (2.5 hrs) and the cheese tray was excellent.  We also got warmed nuts.  They serve Woodford Reserve bourbon, so I was happy.

There is a window, but it is in the forward half of the space, which does not allow the passenger to lean into it, thus reducing the shoulder width by several inches. I choose the window for those extra inches.

Seat 11D and 11E have underseat storage under row 10. Seats 11 A-C do not due to a large device blocking access to row 10.  There is a small space for 11C but not much. Having flown this plane before the width's of the seats are definitely narrower than the other rows but I'm 5'11" and 220 lbs and I fit ok.  The video monitor is on a swing arm and a little clunky and the tray tables come out of the arm rest.   Legroom is very spacious and I couldn't even reach my bag under row 10 without getting up.  11D, E and 12F are the best seats on this plane.

Plenty of legroom but the proximity to the restroom and the large amount of space between rows 23 and 24 make it too tempting for anyone waiting for the restroom to take over that space as the default waiting area.  It's like friggin' Grand Central Station!

I'm an average sized man at 5'10" and 195 pounds and found this seat to be extremely uncomfortable with minimal legroom and foot room (due to power box) taking up 1/2 the space in front of me.   The in flight entertainment unit was nice but did not make up for lack of space.
Overhead bins reserved for First Class. No other storage for your bag, so you are forced to put it farther back in the plane, even in Boarding Group 3.

Pros: You'll have legroom for miles, and the space is also easier to stand up/move around in. 
Cons: It's one of the narrower seats I have encountered on a plane. I don't know if that's the way all the seats in the aisle are; my partner was in 11A and he did not comment on it. Both the media screen and the tray fold out of some portion of the armrest and using both together feels so awkward. There is no under-seat storage because there is a large box that covers your seat and extends halfway across 11A and 11C.11A and 11C do both have under-seat storage, if truncated.  There's also no direct overhead storage so you'll have to just find a spot in one of the other overhead bins and grab it before someone else does. The FA did help with this on our flight and even entering in Group 9, we were able to find spaces.
Other Notes: The media screen folds out from between the seats and is easy to use, once you've figured out where the button release is (it's on the side of your armrest). 11A has a good view out the window.
No overhead space due to Emergency equipment storage.   Also, the below seat space in front is limited due to power boxes.

On the A321 (ver 1), seats 24B and 24 E are substantially narrower that a typical seat, making this uncomfortable unless you are a small person.  The leg room is nice, but it is also located near a labatory, so cwords can encroach on your space.  I would NOT recommend this seat.

Simply dreadful.  Hardly what one expects forward in the cabin. Barely any recline / only just slightly more than economy. 
The food was..., well, inedible - unless you're truly hungry. No USB ports, no electrical sockets of any sort - whatsoever, and no IFE - unless you're using your own device [which you can't re-charge].
American's product sure has declined.

I recently flew this aircraft up from Punta Cana in the Dominican Republic to Charlotte, North Carolina in seat A1 and can only say that this was hardly a 'first-class' seat and/or experience. The seat has virtually no greater pitch [38] than 'Main cabin extra' [35-36], though 1st does have 3 more inches of width [unless you're in a bullhead seat where the tray-table is stowed in the arm-rest, as in row 1]. Additionally, I couldn't fully extend my legs due to the proximity to the bulkhead and, of course, there's no under-seat storage during take-off nor landing.  The heads were the smallest I've ever experienced on a twin-engine commercial flight -  I mean tiny! If you're adult-sized - don't plan on their viability. Finally, OK, this wasn't a prime-/meal-time flight, however PUJ to CLT is a 4 hour [actual flight time - excluding boarding, taxiing, etc] flight and we were only offered chips, pretzels or cookies {with limited beverage options as well} - in '1st' class. Disgraceful. I felt truly sorry for the cabin staff that had to attempt to function in that minute galley. As a 'million-miler', I hate to see AA's product  sink to such a low-level[s]. This is NOT value for money.
The under seat storage is taken up by a power box

AA lists this as an exit row seat. IT IS NOT! 25A and 25F are hut kit rest in row. They even had the nerve to ask me twice if I was willing and able to assist. And like most AA flights out of MIA, the plane is filthy!

Box under the seat was annoying and took up lots of room but worth it considering the IFE American has on this plane. Still worth the box because of the entertainment they have. Legroom wasn't great even though we paid extra for Main Cabin Extra. New plane. Alright flight
